respStmt.name: Kyonnah Price with homographs and regularisation done by Alexis Antonia

editorialDecl.p:
The characters are identified by IDREF pointing to information in the following declarations.
Don Pedro; Prince of Arragon Don John; Bastard brother to Don Pedro Claudio; Young Lord of Florence Benedick; Young Lord of Padua Leonato; Governor of Messina Antonio; Brother to Leonato Hero; Daughter to Leonato Beatrice; Niece to Leonato Conrade; Follower of Don John Borachio; Follower of Don John Song/Epitaph Multiple Speakers
Balthasar; Singer for Don Pedro Margaret; Gentlewoman to Hero Ursula; Gentlewoman to Hero Verges; a Headborough Friar Francis Dogberry; a Constable
a Sexton a Boy a Lord Messenger First Watchman Second Watchman

div2.stage: Enter Leonato Gouernour of Messina, Innogen his wife, Hero his daughter, and Beatrice his Neece, with a messenger.

sp.speaker: Leonato.
sp.p: I Learn in this Letter, that Don Peter of Arragon, comes this night to Messina.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p:
He is very near by this: he was not
three Leagues off when I left him.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
How many Gentlemen have you lost in this
action?

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p: But few of any sort, and none of name.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
A victory is twice itself, when the achiever
brings home full numbers: I find here, that Don Peter hath bestowed much honour on a young Florentine, called Claudio.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p:
Much deserved on his part, and equally remembered by Don Pedro, he hath borne himself beyond the
promise of his age, doing in the figure of a Lamb, the
feats of a Lion, he hath indeed better bettered expectation, than you must expect of me to tell you how.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p:
He hath an Uncle here in Messina, will be very
much glad of it.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p:
I have already delivered him letters, and there
appears much joy in him, even so much, that joy could
not show itself modest enough, without a badge of bitterness.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Did he break out into tears?

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p: In great measure.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: A kind overflow of kindness, there are no faces truer, than those that are so washed, how much better is it to weep at joy, than to joy at weeping?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p:
I pray you, is Seignior Mountanto returned from
the wars, or no?

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p:
I know none of that name, Lady, there was
none such in the army of any sort.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: What is he that you ask for Niece?

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.p: My cousin means Seignior Benedick of Padua

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p: O he is returned, and as pleasant as ever he was.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
He set up his bills here in Messina, & challenged
Cupid at the Flight: and my Uncles fool reading the
Challenge, subscribed for Cupid, and challenged him at
the Burbolt. I pray you, how many hath he killed and
eaten in these wars? But how many hath he killed? for
indeed, I promised to eat all of his killing.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
I'faith Niece, you tax Seignior Benedicke too
much, but he will be meet with you, I doubt it not.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p: He hath done good service Lady in these wars.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
You had musty victual, and he hath holp to
ease it: he is a very valiant Trencher-man, he hath an
excellent stomach.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p: And a good soldier too Lady.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
And a good soldier to a Lady. But what is he
to a Lord?

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p:
A Lord to a Lord, a man to a man, stuffed with
all honourable vertues.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
It is so indeed, he is no less than a stuffed man:
but for the stuffing well, we are all mortal.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
You must not (sir) mistake my Niece, there is
a kind of merry war betwixt Seignior Benedick, & her:
they never meet, but there is a skirmish of wit between
them.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p:
Alas, he gets nothing by that. In our last conflict, four of his five wits went halting off, and now is
the whole man governed with one: so that if he have
wit enough to keep himself warm, let him bear it
for a difference between himself and his horse: For it
is all the wealth that he hath left, to be known a reasonable creature. Who is his companion now? He hath
every month a new sworn brother.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p: Is it possible?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
Very easily possible: he wears his faith but as
the fashion of his hat, it ever changes with the next block.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p:
I see (Lady) the Gentleman is not in your
books.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p:
No, if he were, I would burn my study. But
I pray you, who is his companion? Is there no young
squarer now, that will make a voyage with him to the
devil?

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p:
He is most in the company of the right noble
Claudio.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
O Lord, he will hang upon him like a disease:
he is sooner caught than the pestilence, and the taker
runs presently mad. God help the noble Claudio, if he
have caught the Benedict, it will cost him a thousand
pound ere he be cured.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p: I will hold friends with you Lady.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Do good friend.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: You will ne'er run mad Niece.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: No, not till a hot January.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p: Don Pedro is approached.

div2.stage: Enter don Pedro, Claudio, Benedicke, Balthasar, and Iohn the bastard.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.p:
Good Seignior Leonato, you are come to meet
your trouble: the fashion of the world is to avoid cost,
and you encounter it.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
Never came trouble to my house in the likeness
of your Grace: for trouble being gone, comfort should
remain: but when you depart from me, sorrow abides,
and happiness takes his leave.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.p:
You embrace your charge too willingly: I
think this is your daughter.

sp.speaker: Leonato.
sp.p: Her mother hath many times told me so.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: Were you in doubt that you asked her?

sp.speaker: Leonato.
sp.p:
Seignior Benedicke, no, for then were you a
child.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.p:
You have it full Benedicke, we may guess by
this, what you are, being a man, truly the Lady fathers
herself: be happy Lady, for you are like an honourable
father.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p:
If Seignior Leonato be her father, she would not
have his head on her shoulders for all Messina, as like him
as she is.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
I wonder that you will still be talking, seignior
Benedicke, nobody marks you.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p:
What my dear Lady Disdain! are you yet
living?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
Is it possible Disdain should die, while she
hath such meet food to feed it, as Seignior Benedicke?
Courtesy itself must convert to Disdain, if you come in
her presence.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
Then is courtesy a turncoat, but it is certain I am loved of all Ladies, only you excepted: and
I would I could find in my heart that I had not a hard
heart, for truly I love none.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
A dear happiness to women, they would else
have been troubled with a pernicious Suitor, I thank
God and my cold blood, I am of your humour for that, I
had rather hear my Dog bark at a Crow, than a man
swear he loves me.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
God keep your Ladyship still in that mind,
so some Gentleman or other shall scape a predestinate
scratched face.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
Scratching could not make it worse, and it were
such a face as yours were.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: Well, you are a rare Parrot teacher.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
A bird of my tongue, is better than a beast of
your.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p:
I would my horse had the speed of your tongue,
and so good a continuer, but keep your way in Gods
name, I have done.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
You always end with a Jades trick, I know
you of old.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.p:
This is the sum of all: Leonato, seignior Claudio, and seignior Benedicke; my dear friend Leonato, hath
invited you all, I tell him we shall stay here, at the least
a month, and he heartily prays some occasion may detain us longer: I dare swear he is no hypocrite, but
prays from his heart.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
If you swear, my Lord, you shall not be forsworn, let me bid you welcome, my Lord, being reconciled to the Prince your brother: I owe you all
duty.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p:
I thank you, I am not of many words, but I
thank you.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Please it your grace lead on?

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.p: Your hand Leonato, we will go together.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.p: Benedicke, didst thou note the daughter of seignior Leonato?

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: I noted her not, but I looked on her.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Is she not a modest young Lady?

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
Do you question me as an honest man should
do, for my simple true judgment? or would you have
me speak after my custom, as being a professed tyrant
to their sex?

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.p: No, I pray thee speak in sober judgment.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
Why i'faith methinks she is too low for a hie
praise, too brown for a fair praise, and too little for a
great praise, only this commendation I can afford her,
that were she other than she is, she were unhandsome,
and being no other, but as she is, I do not like her.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.p:
Thou thinkest I am in sport, I pray thee tell me
truly how thou likest her.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
Would you buy her, that you enquire after
her?

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.p: Can the world buy such a jewel?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p:
Yea, and a case to put it into, but speak you this
with a sad brow? Or do you play the flouting iacke, to
tell us Cupid is a good Hare-finder, and Vulcan a rare
Carpenter: Come, in what key shall a man take you to
go in the song?

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.p:
In mine eye, she is the sweetest Lady that ever
I looked on.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
I can see yet without spectacles, and I see no
such matter: there is her cousin, if she were not possessed
with a fury, exceeds her as much in beauty, as the first
of May doth the last of December: but I hope you have
no intent to turn husband, have you?

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.p:
I would scarce trust myself, though I had
sworn the contrary, if Hero would be my wife.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
Is it come to this? in faith hath not the world one
man but he will wear his cap with suspicion? shall I never see a bachelor of three score again? go to i'faith,
if thou wilt needs thrust thy neck into a yoke, wear
the print of it, and sigh away sundays: look, don Pedro
is returned to seek you.

div2.stage: Enter don Pedro, Iohn the bastard.

sp.speaker: Pedr.
sp.p: What secret hath held you here, that you followed not to Leonatoes?

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p:
I would your Grace would constrain me to
tell.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.p: I charge thee on thy allegiance.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p:
You hear, Count Claudio, I can be secret as a
dumb man, I would have you think so (but on my allegiance, mark you this, on my allegiance) he is in
love, With who? now that is your Graces part: mark
how short his answer is, with Hero, Leonatoes short
daughter.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.p: If this were so, so were it uttered.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p:
Like the old tale, my Lord, it is not so, nor it was
not so: but indeed, God forbid it should be so.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.p:
If my passion change not shortly, God forbid it
should be otherwise.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.p:
Amen, if you love her, for the Lady is very
well worthy.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.p: You speak this to fetch me in, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Pedr.
sp.p: By my troth I speak my thought.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.p: And in faith, my Lord, I spoke mine.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p:
And by my two faiths and troths, my Lord, I
speak mine.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.p: That I love her, I feele.

sp.speaker: Pedr.
sp.p: That she is worthy, I know.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p:
That I neither feele how she should be loved, nor know how she should be worthy, is the
opinion that fire cannot melt out of me, I will die in it at
the stake.

sp.speaker: Pedr.
sp.p: Thou wast ever an obstinate heretic in the despite of Beauty.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.p:
And never could maintain his part, but in the
force of his will.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p:
That a woman conceived me, I thank her: that
she brought me up, I likewise give her most humble
thanks: but that I will have a recheat winded in my
forehead, or hang my bugle in an invisible baldrick, all
women shall pardon me: because I will not do them the
wrong to mistrust any, I will do myself the right to
trust none: and the fine is, (for the which I may go the
finer) I will live a Bachelor.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.p: I shall see thee ere I die, look pale with love.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
With anger, with sickness, or with hunger,
my Lord, not with love: prove that ever I loose more
blood with love, than I will get again with drinking,
pick out mine eyes with a Ballet-makers pen,
and
hang me up at the door of a brothel-house for the sign
of blind Cupid.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.p:
Well, if ever thou dost fall from this faith,
thou wilt prove a notable argument.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
If I do, hang me in a bottle like a Cat, & shoot
at me, and he that hits me, let him be clapped on the shoulder, and called Adam.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.p:
Well, as time shall try: In time the savage
Bull doth bear the yoke.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
The savage bull may, but if ever the sensible
Benedicke bear it, pluck off the bulls horns, and set
them in my forehead, and let me be vildly painted, and
in such great Letters as they write, here is good horse
to hire: let them signify under my sign, here you may
see Benedicke the married man.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.p:
If this should ever happen, thou wouldst be
horn mad.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.p:
Nay, if Cupid have not spent all his Quiver in
Venice, thou wilt quake for this shortly.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: I look for an earthquake too then.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.p:
Well, you will temporise with the hours, in
the mean time, good Seignior Benedicke, repair to Leonatoes, commend me to him, and tell him I will not fail
him at supper, for indeed he hath made great preparation.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
I have almost matter enough in me for such an
Embassage, and so I commit you.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.p:
To the tuition of God. From my house, if I
had it.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.p: The sixth of July. Your loving friend, Benedick.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
Nay mock not, mock not; the body of your
discourse is sometime guarded with fragments, and the
guards are but slightly basted on neither, ere you flout
old ends any further, examine your conscience, and so I
leave you.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.l: My Liege, your Highness now may do me
good.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.l: My love is thine to teach, teach it but how,
And thou shalt see how apt it is to learn
Any hard Lesson that may do thee good.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.l: Hath Leonato any son my Lord?

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.l: No child but Hero, she is his only heir.
Dost thou affect her Claudio?

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.l: O my Lord,
When you went onward on this ended action,
I looked upon her with a soldiers eye,
That liked, but had a rougher task in hand,
Than to drive liking to the name of love:
But now I am returned, and that war-thoughts
Have left their places vacant: in their rooms,
Come thronging soft and delicate desires,
All prompting me how fair young Hero is,
Saying I liked her ere I went to wars.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.l: Thou wilt be like a lover presently,
And tire the hearer with a book of words:
If thou dost love fair Hero, cherish it,
And I will break with her: wast not to this end,
That thou beganst to twist so fine a story?

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.l: How sweetly do you minister to love,
That know loves grief by his complexion!
But lest my liking might too sudden seem,
I would have salved it with a longer treatise.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: What need ye bridge much broader than the flood?
The fairest grant is the necessity:
Look what will serve, is fit: it is once, thou lovest,
And I will fit thee with the remedy,
I know we shall have revelling tonight,
I will assume thy part in some disguise,
And tell fair Hero I am Claudio,
And in her bosom I will unclasp my heart,
And take her hearing prisoner with the force
And strong encounter of my amorous tale:
Then after, to her father will I break,
And the conclusion is, she shall be thine,
In practise let us put it presently.

div2.stage: Enter Leonato and an old man, brother to Leonato.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p:
How now brother, where is my cousin your son:
hath he provided this music?

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p:
He is very busy about it, but brother, I can tell
you news that you yet dreamt not of.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Are they good?

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p:
As the events stamps them, but they have a good
cover: they show well outward, the Prince and Count
Claudio walking in a thick pleached alley in my orchard,
were thus overheard by a man of mine: the Prince discovered to Claudio that he loved my niece your daughter, and meant to acknowledge it this night in a dance,
and if he found her accordant, he meant to take the
present time by the top, and instantly break with you
of it.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Hath the fellow any wit that told you this?

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p:
A good sharpe fellow, I will send for him, and
question him yourself.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p:
No, no; we will hold it as a dream, till it appear itself: but I will acquaint my daughter withal,
that she may be the better prepared for an answer, if peradventure this be true: go you and tell her of it: cousins, you know what you have to do, O I cry you mercy friend, go you with me and I will use your skill,
good cousin have a care this busy time.

div2.stage: Enter Sir Iohn the Bastard, and Conrade his companion.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p:
What the good year my Lord, why are you
thus out of measure sad?

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.p:
There is no measure in the occasion that breeds,
therefore the sadness is without limit.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: You should hear reason.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p: And when I have heard it, what blessing bringeth it?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: If not a present remedy, yet a patient sufferance.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.p:
I wonder that thou (being as thou sayst thou art,
born under Saturn) goest about to apply a moral medicine, to a mortifying mischief: I cannot hide what I
am: I must be sad when I have cause, and smile at no
man's jests, eat when I have stomach, and wait for no
man's leisure: sleep when I am drowsy, and tend on no
man's business, laugh when I am merry, and claw no man
in his humour.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p:
Yea, but you must not make the full show of this,
till you may do it without controlment, you have of
late stood out against your brother, and he hath tane
you newly into his grace, where it is impossible you
should take root, but by the fair weather that you make
yourself, it is needful that you frame the season for your
own harvest.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p:
I had rather be a canker in a hedge, than a rose
in his grace, and it better fits my blood to be disdained of
all, than to fashion a carriage to rob love from any: in this
(though I cannot be said to be a flattering honest man)
it must not be denied but I am a plain dealing villain, I
am trusted with a mussel, and enfranchised with a clog,
therefore I have decreed, not to sing in my cage: if I had
my mouth, I would bite: if I had my liberty, I would do
my liking: in the mean time, let me be that I am, and
seek not to alter me.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Can you make no use of your discontent?

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p:
I will make all use of it, for I use it only.
Who comes here? what news Borachio?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.p:
I came yonder from a great supper, the Prince
your brother is royally entertained by Leonato, and I can
give you intelligence of an intended marriage.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p:
Will it serve for any Model to build mischief
on? What is he for a fool that betroths himself to
unquietness?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.p: Marry it is your brothers right hand.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p: Who, the most exquisite Claudio?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.p: Even he.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p:
A proper squire, and who, and who, which way
looks he?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.p: Marry on Hero, the daughter and Heir of Leonato.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p:
A very forward March-chick, how came you
to this?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.p:
Being entertained for a perfumer, as I was smoking a musty room, comes me the Prince and Claudio,
hand in hand in sad conference: I whipped behind the Arras, and there heard it agreed upon, that the Prince should
woo Hero for himself, and having obtained her, give
her to Count Claudio.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p:
Come, come, let us thither, this may prove food
to my displeasure, that young start-up hath all the glory
of my overthrow: if I can cross him any way, I bless
myself every way, you are both sure, and will assist
me?

sp.speaker: Conr.
sp.p: To the death my Lord.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p:
Let us to the great supper, their cheer is the
greater that I am subdued, would the Cook were of my
mind: shall we go prove whats to be done?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.p: We will wait upon your Lordship.

div2.stage: Enter Leonato, his brother, his wife, Hero his daughter, and Beatrice his neece, and a kinsman.

sp.speaker: Leonato.
sp.p: Was not Count Iohn here at supper?

sp.speaker: Brother.
sp.p: I saw him not.

sp.speaker: Beatrice.
sp.p:
How tartly that Gentleman looks, I never
can see him, but I am heart-burned an hour after.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.p: He is of a very melancholy disposition.

sp.speaker: Beatrice.
sp.p:
He were an excellent man that were made
just in the mid-way between him and Benedicke, the one
is too like an image and says nothing, and the other too
like my Ladies eldest son, evermore tattling.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
Then half seignior Benedicks tongue in Count
Iohns mouth, and half Count Iohns melancholy in Seignior Benedicks face.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
With a good leg, and a good foot uncle, and
money enough in his purse, such a man would win any
woman in the world, if he could get her good will.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
By my troth Niece, thou wilt never get thee a
husband, if thou be so shrewd of thy tongue.

sp.speaker: Brother.
sp.p: I'faith she is too cursed.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
Too cursed is more than cursed, I shall lessen Gods
sending that way: for it is said, God sends a cursed Cow
short horns, but to a Cow too cursed he sends none.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
So, by being too cursed, God will send you no
horns.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
Just, if he send me no husband, for the which
blessing, I am at him upon my knees every morning and
evening: Lord, I could not endure a husband with a
beard on his face, I had rather lie in the woollen.

sp.speaker: Leonato.
sp.p:
You may light upon a husband that hath no
beard.

sp.speaker: Batrice.
sp.p:
What should I do with him? dress him in
my apparel, and make him my waiting gentlewoman? he
that hath a beard, is more than a youth: and he that hath
no beard, is less than a man: and he that is more than a
youth, is not for me: and he that is less than a man, I am
not for him: therefore I will even take sixpence in earnest of the Berrord, and lead his Apes into hell.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Well then, go you into hell.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
No, but to the gate, and there will the Devil
meet me like an old Cuckold with horns on his head,
and say, get you to heaven Beatrice, get you to heaven,
here is no place for you maids, so deliver I up my Apes,
and away to S. Peter: for the heavens, he shows me
where the Bachelors sit, and there live we as merry as
the day is long.

sp.speaker: Brother.
sp.p:
Well niece, I trust you will be ruled by your
father.

sp.speaker: Beatrice.
sp.p:
Yes faith, it is my cousins duty to make curtsy, and say, as it please you: but yet for all that cousin, let
him be a handsome fellow, or else make an other curtsy,
and say, father, as it please me.

sp.speaker: Leonato.
sp.p:
Well niece, I hope to see you one day fitted
with a husband.

sp.speaker: Beatrice.
sp.p:
Not till God make men of some other metal than earth, would it not grieve a woman to be overmastered with a piece of valiant dust? to make account of
her life to a clod of wayward marl? no uncle, I will none:
Adams sons are my brethren, and truly I hold it a sin
to match in my kindred.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
Daughter, remember what I told you, if the
Prince do solicit you in that kind, you know your answer.

sp.speaker: Beatrice.
sp.p:
The fault will be in the music cousin, if you
be not wooed in good time: if the Prince be too important, tell him there is measure in everything, & so dance
out the answer, for hear me Hero, wooing, wedding, &
repenting, is as a Scotch jig, a measure, and a cinque-pace: the first suite is hot and hasty like a Scotch jig
(and full as fantastical) the wedding mannerly modest,
(as a measure) full of state & ancientry, and then comes
repentance, and with his bad legs falls into the cinque-pace faster and faster, till he sinks into his grave.

sp.speaker: Leonata.
sp.p: Cousin you apprehend passing shrewdly.

sp.speaker: Beatrice.
sp.p:
I have a good eye uncle, I can see a Church
by daylight.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
The revellers are entering brother, make good
room.

div2.stage: Enter Prince, Pedro, Claudio, and Benedicke, and Balthasar, or dumbe Iohn, Maskers with a drum.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.p: Lady, will you walk about with your friend?

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.p:
So you walk softly, and look sweetly, and say
nothing, I am yours for the walk, and especially when I
walk away.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.p: With me in your company.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.p: I may say so when I please.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.p: And when please you to say so?

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.p:
When I like your favour, for God defend the
Lute should be like the case.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.l: My visor is Philemons roof, within the house
is Love.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.l: Why then your visor should be thatched.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.l: Speak low if you speak Love.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: Well, I would you did like me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
So would not I for your own sake, for I have
many ill qualities.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: Which is one?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I say my prayers aloud.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: I love you the better, the hearers may cry Amen.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: God match me with a good dancer.

sp.speaker: Balt.
sp.p: Amen.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
And God keep him out of my sight when the
dance is done: answer Clarke.

sp.speaker: Balt.
sp.p: No more words, the Clarke is answered.

sp.speaker: Vrsula.
sp.p: I know you well enough, you are Seignior Anthonio.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.p: At a word, I am not.

sp.speaker: Vrsula.
sp.p: I know you by the waggling of your head.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.p: To tell you true, I counterfeit him.

sp.speaker: Vrsu.
sp.p:
You could never do him so ill well, unless
you were the very man: here is his dry hand up & down,
you are he, you are he.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.p: At a word I am not.

sp.speaker: Vrsula.
sp.p:
Come, come, do you think I do not know
you by your excellent wit? can virtue hide itself? go
to, mum, you are he, graces will appear, and there is
an end.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Will you not tell me who told you so?

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: No, you shall pardon me.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Nor will you not tell me who you are?

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: Not now.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
That I was disdainful, and that I had my good
wit out of the hundred merry tales: well, this was Seignior Benedicke that said so.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: What is he?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: I am sure you know him well enough.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: Not I, believe me.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Did he never make you laugh?

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: I pray you what is he?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
Why he is the Princes jester, a very dull fool,
only his gift is, in devising impossible slanders, none
but Libertines delight in him, and the commendation is
not in his wit, but in his villainy, for he both pleaseth
men and angers them, and then they laugh at him, and
beat him: I am sure he is in the Fleet, I would he had
boarded me.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
When I know the Gentleman, I will tell him what
you say.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
Do, do, he will but break a comparison or two
on me, which peradventure (not marked, or not laughed
at) strikes him into melancholy, and then there is a Partridge wing saved, for the fool will eat no supper that
night. We must follow the Leaders.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: In every good thing.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p:
Nay, if they lead to any ill, I will leave them
at the next turning.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p:
Sure my brother is amorous on Hero, and hath
withdrawn her father to break with him about it: the
Ladies follow her, and but one visor remains.

sp.speaker: Borachio.
sp.p: And that is Claudio, I know him by his bearing.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p: Are not you seignior Benedicke?

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.p: You know me well, I am he.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p:
Seignior, you are very near my Brother in his
love, he is enamoured on Hero, I pray you dissuade him
from her, she is no equal for his birth: you may do the
part of an honest man in it.

sp.speaker: Claudio.
sp.p: How know you he loves her?

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p: I heard him swear his affection,

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.p:
So did I too, and he swore he would marry her
tonight.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p: Come, let us to the banquet.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.l: Thus answer I in name of Benedicke,
But hear these ill news with the ears of Claudio:
It is certain so, the Prince woes for himself:
Friendship is constant in all other things,
Save in the Office and affairs of love:
Therefore all hearts in love use their own tongues.
Let every eye negotiate for itself,
And trust no Agent: for beauty is a witch,
Against whose charms, faith melteth into blood:
This is an accident of hourly proof,
Which I mistrusted not. Farewell therefore Hero.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Count Claudio.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.p: Yea, the same.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Come, will you go with me?

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.p: Whither?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p:
Even to the next Willow, about your own business, Count. What fashion will you wear the Garland off? About your neck, like an Usurers chain? Or
under your arm, like a Lieutenants scarf? You must
wear it one way, for the Prince hath got your Hero.

sp.speaker: Clau:
sp.p: I wish him joy of her.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p:
Why that is spoken like an honest Drover, so
they sell Bullocks: but did you think the Prince wold
have served you thus?

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.p: I pray you leave me.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p:
Ho now you strike like the blind man, it was the
boy that stole your meat, and you will beat the post.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.p: If it will not be, I will leave you.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p:
Alas poor hurt fowl, now will he creep into
sedges: But that my Lady Beatrice should know me, &
not know me: the Princes fool! Ha? It may be I go
under that title, because I am merry: yea but so I am
apt to do myself wrong: I am not so reputed, it is the
base (though bitter) disposition of Beatrice, that putt's
the world into her person, and so gives me out: well, I will
be revenged as I may.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.p:
Now Seignior, where is the Count, did you
see him?

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
Troth my Lord, I have played the part of Lady
Fame, I found him here as melancholy as a Lodge in a
Warren, I told him, and I think, told him true, that your
grace had got the will of this young Lady, and I offered
him my company to a willow tree, either to make him a
garland, as being forsaken, or to bind him a rod, as being worthy to be whipped.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.p: To be whipped, what is his fault?

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
The flat transgression of a Schoolboy, who
being overjoyed with finding a birds nest, shows it his
companion, and he steals it.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.p:
Wilt thou make a trust, a transgression? the
transgression is in the staler.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p:
Yet it had not been amiss the rod had been
made, and the garland too, for the garland he might have
worn himself, and the rod he might have bestowed on
you, who (as I take it) have stolen his birds nest.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.p:
I will but teach them to sing, and restore them
to the owner.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
If their singing answer your saying, by my faith
you say honestly.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.p:
The Lady Beatrice hath a quarrel to you, the
Gentleman that danced with her, told her she is much
wronged by you.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
O she misused me past the endurance of a block:
an oak but with one green leaf on it, would have answered her: my very visor began to assume life, and scold
with her: she told me, not thinking I had been myself,
that I was the Princes Jester, and that I was duller
than a great thaw, huddling jest upon jest, with such impossible conveyance upon me, that I stood like a man at a
mark, with a whole army shooting at me: she speaks
poniards, and every word stabs: if her breath were
as terrible as terminations, there were no living near
her, she would infect to the north star: I would not
marry her, though she were endowed with all that Adam
had left him before he transgressed, she would have made
Hercules have turned spit, yea, and have cleft his club to
make the fire too: come, talk not of her, you shall find
her the infernal Ate in good apparel. I would to God
some scholar would conjure her, for certainly while she
is here, a man may live as quiet in hell, as in a sanctuary,
and people sin upon purpose, because they would go
thither, so indeed all disquiet, horror, and perturbation
follows her.

div2.stage: Enter Claudio and Beatrice, Leonato, Hero.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.p: Look here she comes.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
Will your Grace command me any service to
the worlds end? I will go on the slightest errand now
to the Antipodes that you can devise to send me on: I
will fetch you a tooth-picker now from the furthest inch
of Asia: bring you the length of Prester Iohns foot: fetch
you a hair off the great Chams beard: do you any embassage to the Pygmies, rather than hold three words
conference, with this Harpy: you have no employment
for me?

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.p: None, but to desire your good company.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: O God sir, here is a dish I love not, I cannot endure this Lady tongue.

sp.speaker: Pedr.
sp.p:
Come Lady, come, you have lost the heart of
Seignior Benedicke.

sp.speaker: Beatr.
sp.p:
Indeed my Lord, he lent it me a while, and I
gave him use for it, a double heart for a single one, marry
once before he won it of me, with false dice, therefore
your Grace may well say I have lost it.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.p:
You have put him down Lady, you have put
him down.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
So I would not he should do me, my Lord, lest
I should prove the mother of fools: I have brought
Count Claudio, whom you sent me to seek.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.p: Why how now Count, wherefore are you sad?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Not sad my Lord.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.p: How then? sick?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Neither, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
The Count is neither sad, nor sick, nor merry,
nor well: but civil Count, civil as an Orange, and something of a jealous complexion.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.p:
I'faith Lady, I think your blazon to be true,
though I will be sworn, if he be so, his conceit is false:
here Claudio, I have wooed in thy name, and fair Hero
is won, I have broke with her father, and his good will
obtained, name the day of marriage, and God give
thee joy.

sp.speaker: Leona.
sp.p:
Count, take of me my daughter, and with her
my fortunes: his grace hath made the match, & all grace
say, Amen to it.

sp.speaker: Beatr.
sp.p: Speak Count, it is your Cue.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p:
Silence is the perfectest Herald of joy, I were
but little happy if I could say, how much? Lady, as you
are mine, I am yours, I give away myself for you, and
dote upon the exchange.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
Speak cousin, or (if you cannot) stop his mouth
with a kiss, and let not him speak neither.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.p: I'faith Lady you have a merry heart.

sp.speaker: Beatr.
sp.p:
Yea my Lord I thank it, poor fool it keeps
on the windy side of Care, my cousin tells him in his ear
that he is in my heart.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.p: And so she doth cousin.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
Good Lord for alliance: thus goes everyone
to the world but I, and I am sunburned, I may sit in a corner and cry, heigh ho for a husband.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.p: Lady Beatrice, I will get you one.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
I would rather have one of your fathers getting:
hath your Grace ne'er a brother like you? your father
got excellent husbands, if a maid could come by them.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Will you have me? Lady.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
No, my Lord, unless I might have another for
working days, your Grace is too costly to wear every
day: but I beseech your Grace pardon me, I was born
to speak all mirth, and no matter.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p:
Your silence most offends me, and to be merry, best becomes you, for out of question, you were born
in a merry hour.

sp.speaker: Beatr.
sp.p:
No sure my Lord, my Mother cried, but then
there was a star danced, and under that was I born: cousins God give you joy.

sp.speaker: Leonato.
sp.p:
Niece, will you look to those things I told
you of?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: I cry you mercy Uncle, by your Graces pardon.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: By my troth a pleasant spirited Lady.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
There is little of the melancholy element in her
my Lord, she is never sad, but when she sleeps, and not
ever sad then: for I have heard my daughter say, she hath
often dreamt of unhappiness, and waked herself with
laughing.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.p: She cannot endure to hear tell of a husband.

sp.speaker: Leonato.
sp.p:
O, by no means, she mocks all her wooers
out of suite.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: She were an excellent wife for Benedick.

sp.speaker: Leonato.
sp.p:
O Lord, my Lord, if they were but a week
married, they would talk themselves mad.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p:
Count Claudio, when mean you to go to
Church?

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.p:
Tomorrow my Lord, Time goes on crutches,
till Love have all his rites.

sp.speaker: Leonata.
sp.p:
Not till monday, my dear son, which is
hence a just seven night, and a time too brief too, to have
all things answer mind.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p:
Come, you shake the head at so long a breathing, but I warrant thee Claudio, the time shall not go
dully by us, I will in the interim, undertake one of Hercules labours, which is, to bring Seignior Benedicke and the
Lady Beatrice into a mountain of affection, the one with
the other, I would fain have it a match, and I doubt not
but to fashion it, if you three will but minister such assistance as I shall give you direction.

sp.speaker: Leonata.
sp.p:
My Lord, I am for you, though it cost me
ten nights watchings.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: And I my Lord.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: And you to gentle Hero?

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.p:
I will do any modest office, my Lord, to help
my cousin to a good husband.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
And Benedick is not the unhopefullest husband
that I know: thus far can I praise him, he is of a noble
strain, of approved valour, and confirmed honesty, I will
teach you how to humour your cousin,
that she shall fall
in love with Benedicke, and I, with your two helps, will
so practise on Benedicke, that in despite of his quick
wit, and his queasy stomach, he shall fall in love with
Beatrice: if we can do this, Cupid is no longer an Archer, his glory shall be ours, for we are the only love-gods, go in with me, and I will tell you my drift.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.p: It is so, the Count Claudio shall marry the daughter of Leonato.

sp.speaker: Bora.
sp.p: Yea my Lord, but I can cross it.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p:
Any bar, any cross, any impediment, will be
medicinable to me, I am sick in displeasure to him, and
whatsoever comes athwart his affection, ranges evenly
with mine, how canst thou cross this marriage?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.p:
Not honestly my Lord, but so covertly, that no
dishonesty shall appear in me.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p: Show me briefly how.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.p:
I think I told your Lordship a year since, how
much I am in the favour of Margaret, the waiting gentlewoman to Hero.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p: I remember.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.p:
I can at any unseasonable instant of the night,
appoint her to look out at her Ladies chamber window.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p: What life is in that, to be the death of this marriage?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.p:
The poison of that lies in you to temper, go
you to the Prince your brother, spare not to tell him, that
he hath wronged his Honour in marrying the renowned
Claudio, whose estimation do you mightily hold up, to a
contaminated stale, such a one as Hero.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p: What proof shall I make of that?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.p:
Proof enough, to misuse the Prince, to vex
Claudio, to undo Hero, and kill Leonato, look you for any other issue?

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p: Only to despite them, I will endeavour anything.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.p:
Go then, find me a meet hour, to draw on
Pedro and the Count Claudio alone, tell them that you
know that Hero loves me, intend a kind of zeal both
to the Prince and Claudio (as in a love of your brothers
honour who hath made this match) and his friends reputation, who is thus like to be cozened with the semblance
of a maid, that you have discovered thus: they will scarcely believe this without trial: offer them instances which
shall bear no less likelihood, than to see me at her
chamber window, hear me call Margaret, Hero; hear
Margaret term me Claudio, and bring them to see this
the very night before the intended wedding, for in the
mean time, I will so fashion the matter, that Hero shall
be absent, and there shall appear such seeming truths of
Heroes disloyalty, that jealousy shall be called assurance,
and all the preparation overthrown.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p:
Grow this to what adverse issue it can, I will
put it in practise: be cunning in the working this, and
thy fee is a thousand ducats.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.p: Be thou constant in the accusation, and my cunning shall not shame me.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p: I will presently go learn their day of marriage.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: Boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Seignior.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
In my chamber window lies a book, bring it
hither to me in the orchard.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I am here already sir.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
I know that, but I would have thee hence, and
here again. I do much wonder, that one man seeing
how much another man is a fool, when he dedicates his
behaviours to love, will after he hath laughed at such
shallow follies in others, become the argument of his
own scorn, by falling in love, & such a man is Claudio,
I have known when there was no music with him but
the drum and the fife, and now had he rather hear the
tabor and the pipe: I have known when he would have
walked ten mile afoot, to see a good armour, and now will
he lie ten nights awake carving the fashion of a new doublet: he was wont to speak plain, & to the purpose (like
an honest man & a soldier) and now is he turned orthography, his words are a very fantastical banquet, just so
many strange dishes: may I be so converted, & see with
these eyes? I cannot tell, I think not: I will not be
sworn, but love may transform me to an oyster, but I will
take my oath on it, till he have made an oyster of me, he
shall never make me such a fool: one woman is fair, yet
I am well: another is wise, yet I am well: another virtuous, yet I am well: but till all graces be in one woman,
one woman shall not come in my grace: rich she shall
be, that is certain: wise, or I will none: virtuous, or I will never cheapen her: fair, or I will never look on her: mild,
or come not near me: Noble, or not for an Angel: of
good discourse: an excellent Musician, and her hair shall
be of what colour it please God, ha! the Prince and
Monsieur Love, I will hide me in the Arbor.

div2.stage: Enter Prince, Leonato, Claudio, and Iacke Wilson.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: Come, shall we hear this music?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Yea my good Lord: how still the evening is,
As hushed on purpose to grace harmony.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: See you where Benedicke hath hid himself?

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.l: O very well my Lord: the music ended,
We will fit the kid-fox with a penny worth.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Come Balthasar, we will hear that song again.

sp.speaker: Balth.
sp.l: O good my Lord, tax not so bad a voice,
To slander music any more than once.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: It is the witness still of excellency,
To slander music any more than once.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: It is the witness still of excellency,
To put a strange face on his own perfection,
I pray thee sing, and let me woe no more.

sp.speaker: Balth.
sp.l: Because you talk of wooing, I will sing,
Since many a wooer doth commence his suit,
To her he thinks not worthy, yet he woos,
Yet will he swear he loves.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Nay pray thee come,
Or if thou wilt hold longer argument,
Do it in notes.

sp.speaker: Balth.
sp.l: Note this before my notes,
There is not a note of mine that is worth the noting.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Why these are very crotchets that he speaks,
Note notes forsooth, and nothing.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
Now divine air, now is his soul ravished, is it
not strange that sheeps guts should hale souls out of
men's bodies? well, a horn for my money when all is
done.

sp.l: Sigh no more Ladies, sigh no more,
Men were deceivers ever,
One foot in Sea, and one on shore,
To one thing constant never,
Then sigh not so, but let them go,
And be you blithe and bonnie,
Converting all your sounds of woe,
Into hey nonny nonny.
Sing no more ditties, sing no more,
Of dumps so dull and heavy,
The fraud of men were ever so,
Since summer first was leafy,
Then sigh not so, &c.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: By my troth a good song.

sp.speaker: Balth.
sp.p: And an ill singer, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p:
Ha, no, no faith, thou singest well enough for a
shift.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p:
If he had been a dog that should have howled
thus, they would have hanged him, and I pray God his
bad voice bode no mischief, I had as lief have heard
the night-raven, come what plague could have come after it.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p:
Yea marry, dost thou hear Balthasar? I pray
thee get us some excellent music: for tomorrow night
we would have it at the Lady Heroes chamber window.

sp.speaker: Balth.
sp.p: The best I can, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p:
Do so, farewell. Come hither Leonato, what
was it you told me of today, that your Niece Beatrice
was in love with seignior Benedicke?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: O I, stalk on, stalk on, the foul sits. I did never think that Lady would have loved any man.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
No, nor I neither, but most wonderful, that she
should so dote on Seignior Benedicke, whom she hath in
all outward behaviours seemed ever to abhor.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: Is it possible? sits the wind in that corner?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p:
By my troth my Lord, I cannot tell what to
think of it, but that she loves him with an enraged affection, it is past the infinite of thought.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: May be she doth but counterfeit.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Faith like enough.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: O God! counterfeit? there was never counterfeit of passion, came so near the life of passion as she discovers it.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Why what effects of passion shows she?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Bait the hook well, this fish will bite.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
What effects my Lord? she will sit you, you
heard my daughter tell you how.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.p: She did indeed.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
How, how I pray you? you amaze me, I would
have thought her spirit had been invincible against all
assaults of affection.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p:
I would have sworn it had, my Lord, especially
against Benedicke.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
I should think this a gull, but that the white-bearded fellow speaks it: knavery cannot sure hide
himself in such reverence.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: He hath tane the infection, hold it up.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Hath she made her affection known to Benedicke?

sp.speaker: Leonato.
sp.p:
No, and swears she never will, that is her
torment.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p:
It is true indeed, so your daughter says: shall
I, says she, that have so oft encountered him with scorn,
write to him that I love him?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p:
This says she now when she is beginning to
write to him, for she will be up twenty times a night, and
there will she sit in her smock, till she have writ a sheet
of paper: my daughter tells us all.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.p:
Now you talk of a sheet of paper, I remember
a pretty jest your daughter told us of.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
O when she had writ it, & was reading it over,
she found Benedicke and Beatrice between the sheet.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.p: That.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
O she tore the letter into a thousand halfpence,
railed at herself, that she should be so immodest to write,
to one that she knew would flout her: I measure him,
says she, by my own spirit, for I should flout him if he
writ to me, yea though I love him, I should.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.p:
Then down upon her knees she falls, weeps,
sobs, beats her heart, tears her hair, prays, curses, O
sweet Benedicke, God give me patience.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
She doth indeed, my daughter says so, and the
ecstasy hath so much overborne her, that my daughter is
sometime afeared she will do a desperate out-rage to herself,
it is very true.

sp.speaker: Princ.
sp.p:
It were good that Benedicke knew of it by some
other, if she will not discover it.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.p:
To what end? he would but make a sport of it,
and torment the poor Lady worse.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
If he should, it were an alms to hang him,
she is an excellent sweet Lady, and (out of all suspicion,)
she is virtuous.

sp.speaker: Claudio.
sp.p: And she is exceeding wise.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: In everything, but in loving Benedicke.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
O my Lord, wisdom and blood combating in
so tender a body, we have ten proofs to one, that blood
hath the victory, I am sorry for her, as I have just cause,
being her Uncle, and her Guardian.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p:
I would she had bestowed this dotage on
me, I would have daft all other respects, and made her
half myself: I pray you tell Benedicke of it, and hear
what he will say.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Were it good think you?

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.p:
Hero thinks surely she will die, for she says she
will die, if he love her not, and she will die ere she
make her love known, and she will die if he woo her,
rather than she will bate one breath of her accustomed
crossness.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
She doth well, if she should make tender of her
love, it is very possible he will scorn it, for the man (as you
know all) hath a contemptible spirit.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.p: He is a very proper man.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: He hath indeed a good outward happiness.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.p: Before God, and in my mind very wise.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
He doth indeed show some sparks that are like
wit.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: And I take him to be valiant.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
As Hector, I assure you, and in the managing of
quarrels you may see he is wise, for either he avoids
them with great discretion, or undertakes them with a
Christian-like fear.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
If he do fear God, he must necessarily keep
peace, if he break the peace, he ought to enter into a
quarrel with fear and trembling.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
And so will he do, for the man doth fear God,
howsoever it seems not in him, by some large jests he
will make: well, I am sorry for your niece, shall we go
see Benedicke, and tell him of her love.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p:
Never tell him, my Lord, let her wear it out
with good counsel.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
Nay that is impossible, she may wear her heart
out first.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
Well, we will hear further of it by your daughter, let it cool the while, I love Benedicke well, and I
could wish he would modestly examine himself, to see
how much he is unworthy to have so good a Lady.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: My Lord, will you walk? dinner is ready.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.p:
If he do not dote on her upon this, I will never
trust my expectation.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
Let there be the same Net spread for her, and
that must your daughter and her gentlewoman carry:
the sport will be, when they hold one an opinion of another's dotage, and no such matter, that is the Scene that I
would see, which will be merely a dumb show: let us
send her to call him into dinner.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
This can be no trick, the conference was sadly
borne, they have the truth of this from Hero, they seem
to pity the Lady: it seems her affections have the full
bent: love me? why it must be requited: I hear how I
am censured, they say I will bear myself proudly, if I
perceive the love come from her: they say too, that she
will rather die than give any sign of affection: I did never think to marry, I must not seem proud, happy are
they that hear their detractions, and can put them to
mending: they say the Lady is fair, it is a truth, I can
bear them witness: and virtuous, it is so, I cannot reprove it, and wise, but for loving me, by my troth it is
no addition to her wit, nor no great argument of her
folly; for I will be horribly in love with her, I may chance
have some odd quirks and remnants of wit broken
on me, because I have railed so long against marriage:
but doth not the appetite alter? a man loves the meat in
his youth, that he cannot endure in his age. Shall quips
and sentences, and these paper bullets of the brain awe
a man from the career of his humour? No, the world
must be peopled. When I said I would die a bachelor, I
did not think I should live till I were married, here comes
Beatrice: by this day, she is a fair Lady, I do spy some
marks of love in her.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
Against my will I am sent to bid you come in to
dinner.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.l: Fair Beatrice, I thank you for your pains.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
I took no more pains for those thanks, than
you take pains to thank me, if it had been painful, I
would not have come.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: You take pleasure then in the message.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
Yea just so much as you may take upon a knives
point, and choake a daw withal: you have no stomach
seignior, fare you well.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
Ha, against my will I am sent to bid you come
into dinner: there is a double meaning in that: I took
no more pains for those thanks than you took pains
to thank me, that is as much as to say, any pains that I
take for you is as easy as thanks: if I do not take pity
of her I am a villain, if I do not love her I am a Jew, I
will go get her picture.

div2.stage: Enter Hero and two Gentlemen, Margaret, and Vrsula.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.l: Good Margaret run thee to the parlour,
There shalt thou find my Cousin Beatrice,
Proposing with the Prince and Claudio,
Whisper her ear, and tell her I and Vrsula,
Walk in the Orchard, and our whole discourse
Is all of her, say that thou over-heardest us,
And bid her steal into the pleached bower,
Where honeysuckles ripened by the sun,
Forbid the sun to enter: like favourites,
Made proud by Princes, that advance their pride,
Against that power that bred it, there will she hide her,
To listen our purpose, this is thy office,
Bear thee well in it, and leave us alone.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: I will make her come I warrant you presently.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.l: Now Vrsula, when Beatrice doth come,
As we do trace this alley up and down,
Our talk must only be of Benedicke,
When I do name him, let it be thy part,
To praise him more than ever man did merit,
My talk to thee must be how Benedicke
Is sick in love with Beatrice: of this matter,
Is little Cupids crafty arrow made,
That only wounds by hear-say: now begin,
For look where Beatrice like a Lapwing runs
Close by the ground, to hear our conference.

sp.speaker: Vrs.
sp.l: The pleasantest angling is to see the fish
Cut with her golden ores the silver stream,
And greedily devour the treacherous bait:
So angle we for Beatrice, who even now,
Is couched in the woodbine coverture,
Fear you not my part of the Dialogue.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Then go we near her that her ear loose nothing,
Of the false sweet bait that we lay for it:
No truly Vrsula, she is too disdainful,
I know her spirits are as coy and wild,
As Haggards of the rock.

sp.speaker: Vrsula.
sp.l: But are you sure,
That Benedicke loves Beatrice so entirely?

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: So says the Prince, and my new trothed Lord.

sp.speaker: Vrs.
sp.l: And did they bid you tell her of it, Madam?

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: They did entreat me to acquaint her of it,
But I persuaded them, if they loved Benedicke,
To wish him wrestle with affection,
And never to let Beatrice know of it.

sp.speaker: Vrsula.
sp.l: Why did you so, doth not the Gentleman
Deserve as full as fortunate a bed,
As ever Beatrice shall couch upon?

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.l: O God of love! I know he doth deserve,
As much as may be yielded to a man:
But Nature never framed a woman's heart,
Of prouder stuff than that of Beatrice:
Disdain and Scorn ride sparkling in her eyes,
Mis-prizing what they look on, and her wit
Values itself so highly, that to her
All matter else seems weak: she cannot love,
Nor take no shape nor project of affection,
She is so self endeared.

sp.speaker: Vrsula.
sp.l: Sure I think so,
And therefore certainly it were not good
She knew his love, lest she make sport at it.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.l: Why you speak truth, I never yet saw man,
How wise, how noble, young, how rarely featured.
But she would spell him backward: if fair faced,
She would swear the gentleman should be her sister:
If black, why Nature drawing of an antic,
Made a foul blot: if tall, a lance ill headed:
If low, an agot very vildly cut:
If speaking, why a vane blown with all winds:
If silent, why a block moved with none.
So turns she every man the wrong side out,
And never gives to Truth and Virtue, that
Which simpleness and merit purchaseth.

sp.speaker: Vrsu.
sp.l: Sure, sure, such carping is not commendable.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.l: No, not to be so odd, and from all fashions,
As Beatrice is, cannot be commendable,
But who dare tell her so? if I should speak,
She would mock me into air, O she would laugh me
Out of myself, press me to death with wit,
Therefore let Benedicke like covered fire,
Consume away in sighs, waste inwardly:
It were a better death, to die with mocks,
Which is as bad as die with tickling.

sp.speaker: Vrsu.
sp.l: Yet tell her of it, hear what she will say.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.l: No, rather I will go to Benedicke,
And counsel him to fight against his passion,
And truly I will devise some honest slanders,
To stain my cousin with, one doth not know,
How much an ill word may empoison liking.

sp.speaker: Vrsu.
sp.l: O do not do your cousin such a wrong,
She cannot be so much without true judgment,
Having so swift and excellent a wit
As she is prized to have, as to refuse
So rare a Gentleman as seignior Benedicke.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.l: He is the only man of Italy,
Always excepted, my dear Claudio.

sp.speaker: Vrsu.
sp.l: I pray you be not angry with me, Madam,
Speaking my fancy: Seignior Benedicke,
For shape, for bearing argument and valour,
Goes foremost in report through Italy.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.l: Indeed he hath an excellent good name.

sp.speaker: Vrsu.
sp.l: His excellence did earn it ere he had it:
When are you married Madam?

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.l: Why every day tomorrow, come go in,
I will show thee some attires, and have thy counsel,
Which is the best to furnish me tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Vrsu.
sp.l: She is tane I warrant you,
We have caught her Madam?

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.l: If it prove so, then loving goes by haps,
Some Cupid kills with arrows, some with traps.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: What fire is in mine ears? can this be true?
Stand I condemned for pride and scorn so much?
Contempt, farewell, and maiden pride, adieu,
No glory lives behind the back of such.
And Benedicke, love on, I will requite thee,
Taming my wild heart to thy loving hand:
If thou dost love, my kindness shall incite thee
To bind our loves up in a holy band.
For others say thou dost deserve, and I
Believe it better than reportingly.

div2.stage: Enter Prince, Claudio, Benedicke, and Leonato.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: I do but stay till your marriage be consummate, and then go I toward Arragon.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.p: I will bring you thither my Lord, if you will vouchsafe me.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
Nay, that would be as great a soil in the new
gloss of your marriage, as to show a child his new coat
and forbid him to wear it, I will only be bold with
Benedicke for his company, for from the crown of his
head, to the sole of his foot, he is all mirth, he hath twice
or thrice cut Cupids bow-string, and the little hang-man
dare not shoot at him, he hath a heart as sound as a bell,
and his tongue is the clapper, for what his heart thinks,
his tongue speaks.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: Gallants, I am not as I have been.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: So say I, methinks you are sadder.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: I hope he be in love.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
Hang him truant, there is no true drop of blood
in him to be truly touched with love, if he be sad, he wants
money.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: I have the tooth-ach.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: Draw it.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: Hang it.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: You must hang it first, and draw it afterwards.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: What? sigh for the tooth-ach.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Where is but a humour or a worm.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
Well, everyone cannot master a grief, but he
that has it.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.p: Yet say I, he is in love.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
There is no appearance of fancy in him, unless
it be a fancy that he hath to strange disguises, as to be a
Dutchman today, a Frenchman tomorrow: unless he
have a fancy to this foolery, as it appears he hath, he
is no fool for fancy, as you would have it to appear
he is.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.p:
If he be not in love with some woman, there
is no believing old signs, he brushes his hat a mornings,
What should that bode?

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: Hath any man seen him at the Barbers?

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.p:
No, but the Barbers man hath been seen with
him, and the old ornament of his cheek hath already
stuffed tennis balls.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
Indeed he looks younger than he did, by the
loss of a beard.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
Nay he rubs himself with Civet, can you smell
him out by that?

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.p:
That is as much as to say, the sweet youth is in
love.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: The greatest note of it is his melancholy.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.p: And when was he wont to wash his face?

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
Yea, or to paint himself? for the which I hear
what they say of him.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.p:
Nay, but his jesting spirit, which is now crept
into a lute-string, and now governed by stops.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
Indeed that tells a heavy tale for him: conclude,
he is in love.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.p: Nay, but I know who loves him.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p:
That would I know too, I warrant one that
knows him not.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p:
Yes, and his ill conditions, and in despite of all,
dies for him.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: She shall be buried with her face upwards.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
Yet is this no charm for the tooth-ache, old seignior, walk aside with me, I have studied eight or nine
wise words to speak to you, which these hobby-horses
must not hear.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: For my life to break with him about Beatrice.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.p:
It is even so, Hero and Margaret have by this
played their parts with Beatrice, and then the two Bears
will not bite one another when they meet.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.p: My Lord and brother, God save you.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: Good den brother.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.p: If your leisure served, I would speak with you.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: In private?

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.p:
If it please you, yet Count Claudio may hear,
for what I would speak of, concerns him.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: What is the matter?

sp.speaker: Basta.
sp.p: Means your Lordship to be married tomorrow?

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: You know he does.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.p: I know not that when he knows what I know.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.p: If there be any impediment, I pray you discover it.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.p:
You may think I love you not, let that appear
hereafter, and aim better at me by that I now will manifest, for my brother (I think, he holds you well, and in
dearness of heart) hath holp to effect your ensuing
marriage: surely suit ill spent, and labour ill bestowed.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: Why, what is the matter?

sp.speaker: Bastard.
sp.p:
I came hither to tell you, and circumstances
shortened, (for she hath been too long a talking of) the
Lady is disloyal.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.p: Who Hero?

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.p:
Even she, Leonatoes Hero, your Hero, every
man's Hero.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.p: Disloyal?

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.p:
The word is too good to paint out her wickedness, I could say she were worse, think you of a worse
title, and I will fit her to it: wonder not till further warrant: go but with me tonight, you shall see her chamber window entered, even the night before her wedding
day, if you love her, then tomorrow wed her: But it
would better fit your honour to change your mind.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: May this be so?

sp.speaker: Princ.
sp.p: I will not think it.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.p:
If you dare not trust that you see, confess not
that you know: if you will follow me, I will show you
enough, and when you have seen more, & heard more,
proceed accordingly.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.p:
If I see anything tonight, why I should not
marry her tomorrow in the congregation, where I should
wed, there will I shame her.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
And as I wooed for thee to obtain her, I will
join with thee to disgrace her.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.p:
I will disparage her no farther, till you are my
witnesses, bear it coldly but till night, and let the issue
show itself.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: O day untowardly turned!

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: O mischief strangely thwarting!

sp.speaker: Bastard.
sp.p:
O plague right well prevented! so will you
say, when you have seen the sequel.

div2.stage: Enter Dogbery and his compartner with the watch.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p: Are you good men and true?

sp.speaker: Verg.
sp.p:
Yea, or else it were pity but they should suffer
salvation body and soul.

sp.speaker: Dogb.
sp.p:
Nay, that were a punishment too good for
them, if they should have any allegiance in them, being
chosen for the Princes watch.

sp.speaker: Verges.
sp.p:
Well, give them their charge, neighbour
Dogbery.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p:
First, who think you the most desertless man
to be Constable?

sp.speaker: Watch. 1.
sp.p:
Hugh Ote-cake sir, or George Sea-coale, for
they can write and read.

sp.speaker: Dogb.
sp.p:
Come hither neighbour Sea-coale, God hath
blessed you with a good name: to be a well-favoured man,
is the gift of Fortune, but to write and read, comes by
Nature.

sp.speaker: Watch 2.
sp.p: Both which Master Constable

sp.speaker: Dogb.
sp.p:
You have: I knew it would be your answer:
well, for your favour sir, why give God thanks, & make
no boast of it, and for your writing and reading, let that
appear when there is no need of such vanity, you are
thought here to be the most senseless and fit man for the
Constable of the watch: therefore bear you the lantern: this is your charge: You shall comprehend all
vagrom men, you are to bid any man stand in the Princes name.

sp.speaker: Watch 2.
sp.p: How if he will not stand?

sp.speaker: Dogb.
sp.p:
Why then take no note of him, but let him go,
and presently call the rest of the Watch together, and
thank God you are rid of a knave.

sp.speaker: Verges.
sp.p:
If he will not stand when he is bidden, he is
none of the Princes subjects.

sp.speaker: Dogb.
sp.p:
True, and they are to meddle with none but
the Princes subjects: you shall also make no noise in the
streets: for, for the Watch to babble and talk, is most
tolerable, and not to be endured.

sp.speaker: Watch.
sp.p:
We will rather sleep than talk, we know
what belongs to a Watch.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p:
Why you speak like an ancient and most quiet
watchman, for I cannot see how sleeping should offend:
only have a care that your bills be not stolen: well, you
are to call at all the Alehouses, and bid them that are
drunk get them to bed.

sp.speaker: Watch.
sp.p: How if they will not?

sp.speaker: Dogb.
sp.p:
Why then let them alone till they are sober, if
they make you not then the better answer, you may say,
they are not the men you took them for.

sp.speaker: Watch.
sp.p: Well sir.

sp.speaker: Dogb.
sp.p:
If you meet a thief, you may suspect him, by
virtue of your office, to be no true man: and for such
kind of men, the less you meddle or make with them,
why the more is for your honesty.

sp.speaker: Watch.
sp.p:
If we know him to be a thief, shall we not
lay hands on him.

sp.speaker: Dogb.
sp.p:
Truly by your office you may, but I think they
that touch pitch will be defiled: the most peaceable way
for you, if you do take a thief, is, to let him show himself what he is, and steal out of your company.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: You have been always called a merciful man partner.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p:
Truly I would not hang a dog by my will, much
more a man who hath any honesty in him.

sp.speaker: Verges.
sp.p:
If you hear a child cry in the night you must
call to the nurse, and bid her still it.

sp.speaker: Watch.
sp.p:
How if the nurse be asleep and will not
hear us?

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p:
Why then depart in peace, and let the child
wake her with crying, for the ewe that will not hear
her Lamb when it bays, will never answer a calf when
he bleats.

sp.speaker: Verges.
sp.p: It is very true.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p:
This is the end of the charge: you constable
are to present the Princes own person, if you meet the
Prince in the night, you may stay him.

sp.speaker: Verges.
sp.p: Nay byrlady that I think he cannot.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p:
Five shillings to one on it with any man that
knows the Statutes, he may stay him, marry not without the prince be willing, for indeed the watch ought to
offend no man, and it is an offence to stay a man against
his will.

sp.speaker: Verges.
sp.p: Byrlady I think it be so.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p:
Ha, ah ha, well masters good night, and there be
any matter of weight chances, call up me, keep your
fellows counsels, and your own, and good night,
come neighbour.

sp.speaker: Watch.
sp.p:
Well masters, we hear our charge, let us go
sit here upon the Church bench till two, and then all to
bed.

sp.speaker: Dog.
sp.p:
One word more, honest neighbours. I pray you
watch about seignior Leonatoes door, for the wedding being there tomorrow, there is a great coil tonight,
adiew, be vigitant I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.p: What, Conrade?

sp.speaker: Watch.
sp.p: Peace, stir not.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.p: Conrade I say.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Here man, I am at thy elbow.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.p:
Mass and my elbow itched, I thought there would
a scab follow.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p:
I will owe thee an answer for that, and now
forward with thy tale.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.p:
Stand thee close then under this penthouse, for it
drizzles rain, and I will, like a true drunkard, utter all to
thee.

sp.speaker: Watch.
sp.p: Some treason masters, yet stand close.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.p:
Therefore know, I have earned of Don Iohn a
thousand Ducats.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Is it possible that any villainy should be so dear?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.p:
Thou shouldest rather ask if it were possible any villainy should be so rich? for when rich villains have
need of poor ones, poor ones may make what price
they will.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: I wonder at it.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.p:
That shows thou art unconfirmed, thou knowest
that the fashion of a doublet, or a hat, or a cloak, is nothing to a man.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Yes, it is apparel.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.p: I mean the fashion.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Yes the fashion is the fashion.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.p:
Tush, I may as well say the fool is the fool, but
seest thou not what a deformed thief this fashion is?

sp.speaker: Watch.
sp.p:
I know that deformed, he has been a vile thief,
this vii. years, he goes up and down like a gentle man:
I remember his name.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.p: Didst thou not hear somebody?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: No, it was the vain on the house.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.p:
Seest thou not (I say) what a deformed thief
this fashion is, how giddily a turns about all the Hot-bloods, between fourteen & five & thirty, sometimes
fashioning them like Pharaoh's soldiers in the reechy
painting, sometime like god Bels priests in the old
Church window, sometime like the shaven Hercules in
the smirched worm eaten tapestry, where his codpiece
seems as massy as his club.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p:
All this I see, and see that the fashion wears out
more apparel than the man; but art not thou thyself
giddy with the fashion too that thou hast shifted out of
thy tale into telling me of the fashion?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.p:
Not so neither, but know that I have tonight
wooed Margaret the Lady Heroes gentle-woman, by the
name of Hero, she leans me out at her mistress chamber window, bids me a thousand times good night: I tell
this tale vildly. I should first tell thee how the Prince
Claudio and my Master planted, and placed, and possessed
by my Master Don Iohn, saw a far off in the Orchard this
amiable encounter.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: And thought thy Margaret was Hero?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.p:
Two of them did, the Prince and Claudio, but the
devil my Master knew she was Margaret and partly by
his oaths, which first possessed them, partly by the dark
night which did deceive them, but chiefly, by my villainy, which did confirm any slander that Don Iohn had
made, away went Claudio enraged, swore he would
meet her as he was appointed next morning at the Temple, and there, before the whole congregation shame her
with what he saw over night, and send her home again
without a husband.

sp.speaker: Watch. 1.
sp.p: We charge you in the Princes name stand.

sp.speaker: Watch. 2.
sp.p:
Call up the right master Constable, we have
here recovered the most dangerous piece of lechery, that
ever was known in the Common-wealth.

sp.speaker: Watch. 1.
sp.p:
And one Deformed is one of them, I know
him, he wears a lock.

sp.speaker: Conr.
sp.p: Masters, masters.

sp.speaker: Watch. 2.
sp.p: You will be made bring deformed forth I warrant you,

sp.speaker: Conr.
sp.p: Masters,
never speak, we charge you, let us obey you to go with us.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.p: We are like to prove a goodly commodity, being taken up of these men's bills.

sp.speaker: Conr.
sp.p:
A commodity in question I warrant you, come
we will obey you.

div2.stage: Enter Hero, and Margaret, and Vrsula.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.p: Good Vrsula wake my cousin Beatrice, and desire her to rise.

sp.speaker: Vrsu.
sp.p: I will Lady.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: And bid her come hither.

sp.speaker: Vrs.
sp.p: Well.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Troth I think your other rebato were better.

sp.speaker: Bero.
sp.p: No pray thee good Meg, I will wear this.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p:
By my troth's not so good, and I warrant your
cousin will say so.

sp.speaker: Bero.
sp.p:
My cousin is a fool, and thou art another, I will
wear none but this.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
I like the new tire within excellently, if the
hair were a thought browner: and your gown's a most
rare fashion i'faith, I saw the Duchess of Millaines
gown that they praise so.

sp.speaker: Bero.
sp.p: O that exceeds they say.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
By my troth's but a nightgown in respect of
yours, cloth a gold and cuts, and laced with silver, set with
pearls, down sleeves, side sleeves, and skirts, round underborne with a bluish tinsel, but for a fine quaint graceful and excellent fashion, yours is worth ten of it.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.p:
God give me joy to wear it, for my heart is
exceeding heavy.

sp.speaker: Marga.
sp.p:
It will be heavier soon, by the weight of a
man.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.p: Fie upon thee, art not ashamed?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p:
Of what Lady? of speaking honourably? is
not marriage honourable in a beggar? is not your Lord
honourable without marriage? I think you would have
me say, saving your reverence a husband: and bad thinking do not wrest true speaking, I will offend nobody, is
there any harm in the heavier for a husband? none I
think, if it be the right husband, and the right wife,
otherwise it is light and not heavy, ask my Lady Beatrice
else, here she comes.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.p: Good morrow Cuz.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Good morrow sweet Hero.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.p: Why how now? do you speak in the sick tune?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: I am out of all other tune, methinks.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Claps into Light a love, (that goes without a
burden,) do you sing it and I will dance it.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
Ye Light alove with your heels, then if your
husband have stables enough, you will look he shall lack
no barnes.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
O illegitimate construction! I scorn that with
my heels.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
It is almost five o'clock cousin, it is time you
were ready, by my troth I am exceeding ill, hey ho.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: For a hawk, a horse, or a husband?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: For the letter that begins them all, H.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Well, and you be not turned Turk, there is no
more sailing by the star.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: What means the fool trow?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Nothing I, but God send everyone their hearts
desire.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.p:
These gloves the Count sent me, they are an
excellent perfume.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: I am stuffed cousin, I cannot smell.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
A maid and stuffed! there is goodly catching of
cold.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
O God help me, God help me, how long have
you professed apprehension?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Ever since you left it, doth not my wit become
me rarely?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
It is not seen enough, you should wear it in
your cap, by my troth I am sick.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Get you some of this distilled carduus benedictus
and lay it to your heart, it is the only thing for a qualm.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.p: There thou prickest her with a thistle.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Benedictus, why benedictus? you have some moral in this benedictus.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Moral? no by my troth, I have no moral meaning, I meant plain holy thistle, you may think perchance that I think you are in love, nay byrlady I am not
such a fool to think what I list, nor I list not to think
what I can, nor indeed I cannot think, if I would think
my heart out of thinking, that you are in love, or that you
will be in love, or that you can be in love: yet Benedicke
was such another, and now is he become a man, he swore
he would never marry, and yet now in despite of his
heart he eats his meat without grudging, and how you
may be converted I know not, but methinks you look
