with your eyes as other women do.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: What pace is this that thy tongue keeps.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Not a false gallop.

sp.speaker: Vrsula.
sp.p:
Madam, withdraw, the Prince, the Count, seignior Benedicke, Don Iohn, and all the gallants of the
town are come to fetch you to Church.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.p:
Help to dress me good cuz, good Meg,
good Vrsula.

div2.stage: Enter Leonato, and the Constable, and the Headborough.

sp.speaker: Leonato.
sp.p: What would you with me, honest neighbour?

sp.speaker: Const. Dog.
sp.p:
Marry sir I would have some confidence
with you, that discerns you nearly.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
Brief I pray you, for you see it is a busy time
with me.

sp.speaker: Const. Dog.
sp.p: Marry this it is sir.

sp.speaker: Headb.
sp.p: Yes in truth it is sir.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: What is it my good friends?

sp.speaker: Con. Do.
sp.p:
Goodman Verges sir speaks a little of the
matter, an old man sir, and his wits are not so blunt, as
God help I would desire they were, but i'faith honest
as the skin between his brows.

sp.speaker: Head.
sp.p: Yes I thank God, I am as honest as any man living, that is an old man, and no honester than I.

sp.speaker: Con. Dog.
sp.p: Comparisons are odorous, palabras, neighbour Verges.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Neighbours, you are tedious.

sp.speaker: Con. Dog.
sp.p:
It pleases your worship to say so, but we are
the poor Dukes officers, but truly for mine own part,
if I were as tedious as a King I could find in my heart to
bestow it all of your worship.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: All thy tediousness on me, ah?

sp.speaker: Const.Dog.
sp.p:
Yea, and it were a thousand times more
than it is, for I hear as good exclamation on your Worship as of any man in the City, and though I be but a
poor man, I am glad to hear it.

sp.speaker: Head.
sp.p: And so am I.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: I would fain know what you have to say.

sp.speaker: Head.
sp.p:
Marry sir our watch tonight, excepting your
worships presence, have tane a couple of as arrant
knaves as any in Messina.

sp.speaker: Con. Dog.
sp.p:
A good old man sir, he will be talking as
they say, when the age is in the wit is out, God help us,
it is a world to see: well said i'faith neighbour Verges,
well, God's a good man, and two men ride of a horse,
one must ride behind, an honest soul i'faith sir, by my
troth he is, as ever broke bread, but God is to be worshipped, all men are not alike, alas good neighbour.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Indeed neighbour he comes too short of you.

sp.speaker: Con. Do.
sp.p: Gifts that God gives.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: I must leave you.

sp.speaker: Con. Dog.
sp.p:
One word sir, our watch sir have indeed
comprehended two auspicious persons, & we would have
them this morning examined before your worship.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
Take their examination yourself, and bring it
me, I am now in great haste, as may appear unto you.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: It shall be suffisance.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Drink some wine ere you go: fare you well.

sp.speaker: Messenger.
sp.p:
My Lord, they stay for you to give your
daughter to her husband.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: I will wait upon them, I am ready.

sp.speaker: Dogb.
sp.p:
Go good partner, go get you to Francis Seacoale, bid him bring his pen and inkhorn to the Gaol:
we are now to examine those men.

sp.speaker: Verges.
sp.p: And we must do it wisely.

sp.speaker: Dogb.
sp.p:
We will spare for no wit I warrant you:
here is that shall drive some of them to a non-come, only get the learned writer to set down our excommunication, and meet me at the Jail.

div2.stage: Enter Prince, Bastard, Leonato, Frier, Claudio, Benedicke, Hero, and Beatrice.

sp.speaker: Leonato.
sp.p:
Come Friar Francis, be brief, only to the
plain form of marriage, and you shall recount their particular duties afterwards.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: You come hither, my Lord, to marry this Lady.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: To be married to her: Friar, you come to marry her.

sp.speaker: Frier.
sp.p:
Lady, you come hither to be married to this
Count.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.p: I do.

sp.speaker: Frier.
sp.p:
If either of you know any inward impediment
why you should not be conjoined, I charge you on your
souls to utter it.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p: Know you any, Hero?

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.p: None my Lord.

sp.speaker: Frier.
sp.p: Know you any, Count?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: I dare make his answer, None.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.p:
O what men dare do! what men may do! what
men daily do!

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
How now! interjections? why then, some be
of laughing, as ha, ha, he.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.l: Stand thee by Friar, father, by your leave,
Will you with free and unconstrained soul
Give me this maid your daughter?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: As freely son as God did give her me.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: And what have I to give you back, whose worth
May counterpoise this rich and precious gift?

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Nothing, unless you render her again.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.l: Sweet Prince, you learn me noble thankfulness:
There Leonato, take her back again,
Give not this rotten Orange to your friend,
She is but the sign and semblance of her honour:
Behold how like a maid she blushes here!
O what authority and show of truth
Can cunning sin cover itself withal!
Comes not that blood, as modest evidence,
To witness simple Virtue? would you not swear
All you that see her, that she were a maid,
By these exterior shows? But she is none:
She knows the heat of a luxurious bed:
Her blush is guiltiness, not modesty.

sp.speaker: Leonato.
sp.l: What do you mean, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.l: Not to be married,
Not to knit my soul to an approved wanton.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Dear my Lord, if you in your own proof,
Have vanquished the resistance of her youth,
And made defeat of her virginity.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.l: I know what you would say: if I have known her,
You will say, she did embrace me as a husband,
And so extenuate the forehand sin: No Leonato,
I never tempted her with word too large,
But as a brother to his sister, showed
Bashful sincerity and comely love.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.l: And seemed I ever otherwise to you?

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.l: Out on thee seeming, I will write against it,
You seem to me as Diane in her Orb,
As chaste as is the bud ere it be blown:
But you are more intemperate in your blood,
Than Venus, or those pampered animals,
That rage in savage sensuality.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.l: Is my Lord well, that he doth speak so wide?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Sweet Prince, why speak not you?

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: What should I speak?
I stand dishonoured that have gone about,
To link my dear friend to a common stale.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Are these things spoken, or do I but dream?

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.l: Sir, they are spoken, and these things are true.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.l: This looks not like a nuptial.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.l: True, O God!

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.l: Leonato, stand I here?
Is this the Prince? is this the Princes brother?
Is this face Heroes? are our eyes our own?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: All this is so, but what of this my Lord?

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.l: Let me but move one question to your daughter,
And by that fatherly and kindly power,
That you have in her, bid her answer truly.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I charge thee do, as thou art my child.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.l: O God defend me how am I beset,
What kind of catechising call you this?

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.l: To make you answer truly to your name.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.l: Is it not Hero? who can blot that name
With any just reproach?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Marry that can Hero,
Hero itself can blot out Heroes virtue.
What man was he, talked with you yesternight,
Out at your window betwixt twelve and one?
Now if you are a maid, answer to this.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.l: I talked with no man at that hour my Lord.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Why then you are no maiden. Leonato,
I am sorry you must hear: upon mine honour,
Myself, my brother, and this grieved Count
Did see her, hear her, at that hour last night,
Talk with a ruffian at her chamber window,
Who hath indeed most like a liberal villain,
Confessed the vile encounters they have had
A thousand times in secret.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Fie, fie, they are not to be named my Lord,
Not to be spoken of,
There is not chastity enough in language,
Without offence to utter them: thus pretty Lady
I am sorry for thy much misgovernment.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: O Hero! what a Hero hadst thou been
If half thy outward graces had been placed
About thy thoughts and counsels of thy heart?
But fare thee well, most foul, most fair, farewell
Thou pure impiety, and impious purity,
For thee I will lock up all the gates of Love,
And on my eye-lids shall Conjecture hang,
To turn all beauty into thoughts of harm,
And never shall it more be gracious.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Hath no man's dagger here a point for me?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Why how now cousin, wherefore sink you down?

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.l: Come, let us go: these things come thus to light,
Smother her spirits up.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.l: How doth the Lady?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Dead I think, help uncle,
Hero, why Hero, Uncle, Seignior Benedicke, Friar.

sp.speaker: Leonato.
sp.l: O Fate! take not away thy heavy hand,
Death is the fairest cover for her shame
That may be wished for.

sp.speaker: Beatr.
sp.l: How now cousin Hero?

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Have comfort Lady.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Dost thou look up?

sp.speaker: Frier.
sp.l: Yea, wherefore should she not?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Wherefore? Why doth not every earthly thing
Cry shame upon her? Could she here deny
The story that is printed in her blood?
Do not live Hero, do not ope thine eyes:
For did I think thou wouldst not quickly die,
Thought I thy spirits were stronger than thy shames,
Myself would on the reward of reproaches
Strike at thy life. Grieved I, I had but one?
Chid I, for that at frugal Natures frame?
O one too much by thee: why had I one?
Why ever wast thou lovely in my eyes?
Why had I not with charitable hand
Took up a beggars issue at my gates,
Who smeared thus, and mired with infamy,
I might have said, no part of it is mine:
This shame derives itself from unknown loins,
But mine, and mine I loved, and mine I praised,
And mine that I was proud on mine so much,
That I myself, was to myself not mine:
Valuing of her, why she, O she is fallen
Into a pit of Ink, that the wide sea
Hath drops too few to wash her clean again,
And salt too little, which may season give
To her foul tainted flesh.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Sir, sir, be patient: for my part, I am so attired
in wonder, I know not what to say.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: O on my soul my cousin is belied.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Lady, were you her bedfellow last night?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: No truly: not although until last night,
I have this twelve-month been her bedfellow.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Confirmed, confirmed, O that is stronger made
Which was before barred up with ribs of iron.
Would the Princes lie, and Claudio lie,
Who loved her so, that speaking of her foulness,
Washed it with tears? Hence from her, let her die.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Hear me a little, for I have only been silent so
long, and given way unto this course of fortune, by noting of the Lady, I have marked.
A thousand blushing apparitions,
To start into her face, a thousand innocent shames,
In Angel whiteness bear away those blushes,
And in her eye there hath appeared a fire
To burn the errors that these Princes hold
Against her maiden truth. Call me a fool,
Trust not my reading, nor my observations,
Which with experimental seal doth warrant
The tenure of my book: trust not my age,
My reverence, calling, nor divinity,
If this sweet Lady lie not guiltless here,
Under some biting error.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Friar, it cannot be:
Thou seest that all the Grace that she hath left,
Is, that she will not add to her damnation,
A sin of perjury, she not denies it:
Why seekest thou then to cover with excuse,
That which appears in proper
nakedness?

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Lady, what man is he you are accused of?

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.l: They know that do accuse me, I know none:
If I know more of any man alive
Than that which maiden modesty doth warrant,
Let all my sins lack mercy. O my Father,
Prove you that any man with me conversed,
At hours unmeet, or that I yesternight
Maintained the change of words with any creature,
Refuse me, hate me, torture me to death.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: There is some strange misprision in the Princes.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Two of them have the very bent of honour,
And if their wisdoms be misled in this:
The practise of it lives in Iohn the bastard,
Whose spirits toil in frame of villainies.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I know not: if they speak but truth of her,
These hands shall tear her: If they wrong her honour,
The proudest of them shall well hear of it.
Time hath not yet so dried this blood of mine,
Nor age so eat up my invention,
Nor Fortune made such havoc of my means,
Nor my bad life reft me so much of friends,
But they shall find, awaked in such a kind,
Both strength of limb, and policy of mind,
Ability in means, and choice of friends,
To quit me of them thoroughly.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Pause awhile:
And let my counsel sway you in this case,
Your daughter here the Princess (left for dead)
Let her awhile be secretly kept in,
And publish it, that she is dead indeed:
Maintain a mourning ostentation,
And on your Families old monument,
Hang mournful Epitaphs, and do all rites,
That appertain unto a burial.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: What shall become of this? What will this do?

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Marry this well carried, shall on her behalf,
Change slander to remorse, that is some good,
But not for that dream I on this strange course,
But on this travail look for greater birth:
She dying, as it must be so maintained,
Upon the instant that she was accused,
Shall be lamented, pitied, and excused
Of every hearer: for it so falls out,
That what we have, we prize not to the worth,
Whiles we enjoy it; but being lacked and lost,
Why then we rack the value, then we find
The virtue that possession would not show us
Whiles it was ours, so will it fare with Claudio:
When he shall hear she died upon his words,
the idea of her life shall sweetly creep
Into his study of imagination.
And every lovely Organ of her life,
Shall come apparelled in more precious habit:
More moving delicate, and full of life,
Into the eye and prospect of his soul
Then when she lived indeed: then shall he mourn,
If ever Love had interest in his Liver,
And wish he had not so accused her:
No, though he thought his accusation true:
Let this be so, and doubt not but success
Will fashion the event in better shape,
Then I can lay it down in likelihood.
But if all aim but this be leveled false,
The supposition of the Ladies death,
Will quench the wonder of her infamy.
And if it sort not well, you may conceal her,
As best befits her wounded reputation,
In some reclusive and religious life,
Out of all eyes, tongues, minds and injuries.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.l: Seignior Leonato, let the Friar advise you,
And though you know my inwardness and love
Is very much unto the Prince and Claudio.
Yet, by mine honour, I will deal in this,
As secretly and justly, as your soul
Should with your body.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Being that I flow in grief,
The smallest twine may lead me.

sp.speaker: Frier.
sp.l: It is well consented, presently away,
For to strange sores, strangely they strain the cure,
Come Lady, die to live, this wedding day
Perhaps is but prolonged, have patience & endure.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: Lady Beatrice, have you wept all this while?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Yea, and I will weep a while longer.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: I will not desire that.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: You have no reason, I do it freely.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: Surely I do believe your fair cousin is wronged.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
Ah, how much might the man deserve of me
that would right her!

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: Is there any way to show such friendship?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: A very even way, but no such friend.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: May a man do it?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: It is a man's office, but not yours.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
I do love nothing in the world so well as you,
is not that strange?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
As strange as the thing I know not, it were as
possible for me to say, I loved nothing so well as you, but
believe me not, and yet I lie not, I confess nothing, nor
I deny nothing, I am sorry for my cousin.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: By my sword Beatrice thou lovest me.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Do not swear by it and eat it.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
I will swear by it that you love me, and I will
make him eat it that says I love not you.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Will you not eat your word?

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: With no sauce that can be devised to it, I protest I love thee.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Why then God forgive me.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: What offence sweet Beatrice?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: You have stayed me in a happy hour, I was about to protest I loved you.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: And do it with all thy heart.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
I love you with so much of my heart, that none
is left to protest.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: Come, bid me do anything for thee.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Kill Claudio.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: Ha, not for the wide world.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: You kill me to deny, farewell.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: Tarry sweet Beatrice.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
I am gone, though I am here, there is no love
in you, nay I pray you let me go.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: Beatrice.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: In faith I will go.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: We will be friends first.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
You dare easier be friends with me, than fight
with mine enemy.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: Is Claudio thine enemy?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
Is he not approved in the height a villain, that
hath slandered, scorned, dishonoured my kinswoman? O
that I were a man! what, bear her in hand until they
come to take hands, and then with public accusation
uncovered slander, unmitigated rancour? O God that I
were a man! I would eat his heart in the market-place.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: Hear me Beatrice.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
Talk with a man out at a window, a proper
saying.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: Nay but Beatrice.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
Sweet Hero, she is wronged, she is slandered,
she is undone.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: Beat?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
Princes and Counties! surely a Princely testimony, a goodly Count, Comfect, a sweet Gallant surely, O that I were a man for his sake! or that I had any
friend would be a man for my sake! But manhood is melted into curtsies, valour into complement, and men are
only turned into tongue, and trim ones too: he is now
as valiant as Hercules, that only tells a lie, and swears it:
I cannot be a man with wishing, therefore I will die a woman with grieving.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: Tarry good Beatrice, by this hand I love thee.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Use it for my love some other way than swearing by it.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p:
Think you in your soul the Count Claudio
hath wronged Hero?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Yea, as sure as I have a thought, or a soul.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
Enough, I am engaged, I will challenge him, I
will kiss your hand, and so leave you: by this hand Claudio shall render me a dear account: as you hear of me,
so think of me: go comfort your cousin, I must say she
is dead, and so farewell.

div2.stage: Enter the Constables, Borachio, and the Towne Clerke in gownes.

sp.speaker: Keeper.
sp.p: Is our whole dissembly appeared?

sp.speaker: Cowley.
sp.p: O a stool and a cushion for the Sexton.

sp.speaker: Sexton.
sp.p: Which be the malefactors?

sp.speaker: Andrew.
sp.p: Marry that am I, and my partner.

sp.speaker: Cowley.
sp.p:
Nay that is certain, we have the exhibition
to examine.

sp.speaker: Sexton.
sp.p: But which are the offenders that are to be examined, let them come before master Constable.

sp.speaker: Kemp.
sp.p:
Yea marry, let them come before me, what is
your name, friend?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.p: Borachio.

sp.speaker: Kem.
sp.p: Pray write down Borachio. Yours sirrah.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: I am a Gentleman sir, and my name is Conrade.

sp.speaker: Kee.
sp.p:
Write down Master gentleman Conrade: masters, do you serve God: masters, it is proved already
that you are little better than false knaves, and it will go
near to be thought so shortly, how answer you for
yourselves?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Marry sir, we say we are none.

sp.speaker: Kemp.
sp.p:
A marvelous witty fellow I assure you, but I
will go about with him: come you hither sirrah, a word
in your ear sir, I say to you, it is thought you are false
knaves.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.p: Sir, I say to you, we are none.

sp.speaker: Kemp.
sp.p:
Well, stand aside, before God they are both in
a tale: have you writ down that they are none?

sp.speaker: Sext.
sp.p: Master Constable, you go not the way to examine, you must call forth the watch that are their accusers.

sp.speaker: Kemp.
sp.p:
Yea marry, that is the eftest way, let the watch
come forth: masters, I charge you in the Princes name,
accuse these men.

sp.speaker: Watch 1.
sp.p:
This man said sir, that Don Iohn the Princes
brother was a villain.

sp.speaker: Kemp.
sp.p:
Write down, Prince Iohn a villain: why this
is flat perjury, to call a Princes brother villain.

sp.speaker: Bora.
sp.p: Master Constable.

sp.speaker: Kemp.
sp.p:
Pray thee fellow peace, I do not like thy look
I promise thee.

sp.speaker: Sexton.
sp.p: What heard you him say else?

sp.speaker: Watch 2.
sp.p: Marry that he had received a thousand Ducats of Don Iohn, for accusing the Lady Hero wrongfully.

sp.speaker: Kemp.
sp.p: Flat Burglary as ever was committed.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Yea by the mass that it is.

sp.speaker: Sexton.
sp.p: What else fellow?

sp.speaker: Watch 1.
sp.p:
And that Count Claudio did mean upon his
words, to disgrace Hero before the whole assembly, and
not marry her.

sp.speaker: Kemp.
sp.p: O villain! thou wilt be condemned into everlasting redemption for this.

sp.speaker: Sexton.
sp.p: What else?

sp.speaker: Watch.
sp.p: This is all.

sp.speaker: Sexton.
sp.p:
And this is more masters than you can deny,
Prince Iohn is this morning secretly stolen away: Hero
was in this manner accused, in this very manner refused,
and upon the grief of this suddenly died: Master Constable, let these men be bound, and brought to Leonato,
I will go before, and show him their examination.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Come, let them be opinioned.

sp.speaker: Sex.
sp.p: Let them be in the hands of Coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Kem.
sp.p:
Gods my life, where is the Sexton? let him write
down the Princes Officer Coxcomb: come, bind them
thou naughty varlet.

sp.speaker: Couley.
sp.p: Away, you are an ass, you are an ass.

sp.speaker: Kemp.
sp.p:
Dost thou not suspect my place? dost thou not
suspect my years? O that he were here to write me
down an ass! but masters, remember that I am an ass:
though it be not written down, yet forget not that I am an
ass: No thou villain, you art full of piety as shall be proved
upon thee by good witness, I am a wise fellow, and
which is more, an officer, and which is more, a householder, and which is more, as pretty a piece of flesh as any in
Messina, and one that knows the Law, go to, & a rich
fellow enough, go to, and a fellow that hath had losses,
and one that hath two gowns, and everything handsome about him: bring him away: O that I had been writ
down an ass!

sp.speaker: Brother.
sp.l: If you go on thus, you will kill yourself,
And it is not wisdom thus to second grief,
Against yourself.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I pray thee cease thy counsel,
Which falls into mine ears as profitless,
As water in a sieve: give not me counsel,
Nor let no comfort delight mine ear,
But such a one whose wrongs doth suit with mine.
Bring me a father that so loved his child,
Whose joy of her is overwhelmed like mine,
And bid him speak of patience,
Measure his woe the length and breadth of mine,
And let it answer every strain for strain,
As thus for thus, and such a grief for such,
In every lineament, branch, shape, and form:
If such a one will smile and stroke his beard,
And sorrow, wag, cry hem, when he should groan,
Patch grief with proverbs, make misfortune drunk,
With candle-wasters: bring him yet to me,
And I of him will gather patience:
But there is no such man, for brother, men
Can counsel, and speak comfort to that grief,
Which they themselves not feele, but tasting it,
Their counsel turns to passion, which before,
Would give preceptial medicine to rage,
Fetter strong madness in a silken thread,
Charm ache with air, and agony with words,
No, no, it is all men's office, to speak patience
To those that wring under the load of sorrow:
But no man's virtue nor sufficiency
To be so moral, when he shall endure
The like himself: therefore give me no counsel,
My griefs cry louder than advertisement.

sp.speaker: Broth.
sp.l: Therein do men from children nothing differ.

sp.speaker: Leonato.
sp.l: I pray thee peace, I will be flesh and blood,
For there was never yet Philosopher,
That could endure the tooth-ache patiently,
How ever they have writ the style of gods,
And made a push at chance and sufferance.

sp.speaker: Brother.
sp.l: Yet bend not all the harm upon yourself,
Make those that do offend you, suffer too.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: There thou speakest reason, nay I will do so,
My soul doth tell me, Hero is belied,
And that shall Claudio know, so shall the Prince,
And all of them that thus dishonour her.

sp.speaker: Brot.
sp.l: Here comes the Prince and Claudio hastily.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Good den, good den.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.l: Good day to both of you.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Hear you my Lords?

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: We have some haste Leonato.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Some haste my Lord! well, fare you well my Lord,
Are you so hasty now? well, all is one.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Nay, do not quarrel with us, good old man.

sp.speaker: Brot.
sp.l: If he could rite himself with quarrelling,
Some of us would lie low.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Who wrongs him?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Marry you dost wrong me, thou dissembler, thou:
Nay, never lay thy hand upon thy sword,
I fear thee not.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Marry beshrew my hand,
If it should give your age such cause of fear,
I'faith my hand meant nothing to my sword.

sp.speaker: Leonato.
sp.l: Tush, tush, man, never fleer and jest at me,
I speak not like a dotard, nor a fool,
As under privilege of age to brag,
What I have done being young, or what would do,
Were I not old, know Claudio to thy head,
Thou hast so wronged my innocent child and me,
That I am forced to lay my reverence by,
And with grey hairs and bruise of many days,
Do challenge thee to trial of a man,
I say thou hast belied mine innocent child.
Thy slander hath gone through and through her heart,
And she lies buried with her ancestors:
O in a tomb where never scandal slept,
Save this of hers, framed by thy villainy.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: My villainy?

sp.speaker: Leonato.
sp.l: Thine Claudio, thine I say.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: You say not right old man.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: My Lord, my Lord,
I will prove it on his body if he dare,
Despite his nice fence, and his active practise,
His May of youth, and bloom of lustihood.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: Away, I will not have to do with you.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Canst thou so doff me? thou hast killed my child,
If thou killest me, boy, thou shalt kill a man.

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.l: He shall kill two of us, and men indeed,
But that no matter, let him kill one first:
Win me and wear me, let him answer me,
Come follow me boy, come sir boy, come follow me
Sir boy, I will whip you from your foining fence,
Nay, as I am a gentleman, I will.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Brother.

sp.speaker: Brot.
sp.l: Content yourself, God knows I loved my niece,
And she is dead, slandered to death by villains,
That dare as well answer a man indeed,
As I dare take a serpent by the tongue.
Boys, apes, braggarts, Iackes, milk-sops.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Brother Anthony.

sp.speaker: Brot.
sp.l: Hold you content, what man? I know them, yea
And what they weigh, even to the utmost scruple,
Scambling, out-facing, fashion-mongering boys,
That lie, and cog, and flout, deprave, and slander,
Go antiquely, and show outward hideousness,
And speak of half a dozen dangerous words,
How they might hurt their enemies, if they durst.
And this is all.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: But brother Anthonie.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Come, it is no matter,
Do not you meddle, let me deal in this.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Gentlemen both, we will not wake your patience
My heart is sorry for your daughters death:
But on my honour she was charged with nothing
But what was true, and very full of proof.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: My Lord, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: I will not hear you.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: No come brother, away, I will be heard.

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.l: And shall, or some of us will smart for it.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: See, see, here comes the man we went to seek.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.p: Now seignior, what news?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Good day my Lord.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
Welcome seignior, you are almost come to part
almost a fray.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.p:
We had liked to have had our two noses snapped
off with two old men without teeth.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
Leonato and his brother, what thinkest thou? had
we fought, I doubt we should have been too young for
them.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p:
In a false quarrel there is no true valour, I came
to seek you both.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.p:
We have been up and down to seek thee, for
we are high proof melancholy, and would fain have it
beaten away, wilt thou use thy wit?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: It is in my scabbard, shall I draw it?

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: Doest thou wear thy wit by thy side?

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.p:
Never any did so, though very many have been
beside their wit, I will bid thee draw, as we do the minstrels, draw to pleasure us.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
As I am an honest man he looks pale, art thou
sick, or angry?

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.p:
What, courage man: what though care killed a
cat, thou hast mettle enough in thee to kill care.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p:
Sir, I shall meet your wit in the career, and
you charge it against me, I pray you choose another subject.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.p:
Nay then give him another staff, this last was
broke cross.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
By this light, he changes more and more, I think
he be angry indeed.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.p: If he be, he knows how to turn his girdle.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Shall I speak a word in your ear?

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.p: God bless me from a challenge.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p:
You are a villain, I jest not, I will make it good
how you dare, with what you dare, and when you dare:
do me right, or I will protest your cowardice: you have
killed a sweet Lady, and her death shall fall heavy on
you, let me hear from you.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.p:
Well, I will meet you, so I may have good
cheer.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: What, a feast, a feast?

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.p:
I'faith I thank him, he hath bid me to a calves
head and a Capon, the which if I do not carve most curiously, say my knife's nought, shall I not find a woodcock too?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Sir, your wit ambles well, it goes easily.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
I will tell thee how Beatrice praised thy wit the other day: I said thou hadst a fine wit: true says she, a fine
little one: no said I, a great wit: right says she, a great
gross one: nay said I, a good wit: just said she, it hurts
nobody: nay said I, the gentleman is wise: certain said
she, a wise gentleman: nay said I, he hath the tongues:
that I believe said she, for he swore a thing to me on
monday night, which he forswore on tuesday morning:
there is a double tongue, there is two tongues: thus did
she an hour together trans-shape thy particular vertues, yet at last she concluded with a sigh, thou wast the
properest man in Italie.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.p:
For the which she wept heartily, and said she
cared not.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
Yea that she did, but yet for all that, and if she
did not hate him deadly, she would love him dearly,
the old man's daughter told us all.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.p:
All, all, and moreover, God saw him when he
was hid in the garden.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
But when shall we set the savage Bulls horns
on the sensible Benedicks head?

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.p: Yea and text under-neath, here dwells Benedicke the married man.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p:
Fare you well, Boy, you know my mind, I will
leave you now to your gossip-like humour, you break
jests as braggarts do their blades, which God be thanked hurt not: my Lord, for your many courtesies I thank
you, I must discontinue your company, your brother
the Bastard is fled from Messina: you have among you,
killed a sweet and innocent Lady: for my Lord Lack-beard there, he and I shall meet, and till then peace be
with him.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: He is in earnest.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.p:
In most profound earnest, and I will warrant you,
for the love of Beatrice.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: And hath challenged thee.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.p: Most sincerely.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
What a pretty thing man is, when he goes in his
doublet and hose, and leaves off his wit.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.p:
He is then a Giant to an Ape, but then is an Ape
a Doctor to such a man.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
But soft you, let me be, pluck up my heart, and
be sad, did he not say my brother was fled?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p:
Come you sir, if justice cannot tame you, she
shall ne'er weigh more reasons in her balance, nay, and
you be a cursing hypocrite once, you must be looked to.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: How now, two of my brothers men bound? Borachio one.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.p: Hearken after their offence my Lord.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: Officers, what offence have these men done?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p:
Marry sir, they have committed false report,
moreover they have spoken untruths, secondarily they
are slanders, sixth and lastly, they have belied a Lady,
thirdly, they have verified unjust things, and to conclude
they are lying knaves.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
First I ask thee what they have done, thirdly
I ask thee what is their offence, sixth and lastly why they
are committed, and to conclude, what you lay to their
charge.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.p:
Rightly reasoned, and in his own division, and
by my troth there is one meaning well suited.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p:
Who have you offended masters, that you are
thus bound to your answer? this learned Constable is too
cunning to be understood, what is your offence?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.p:
Sweet Prince, let me go no farther to mine answer: do you hear me, and let this Count kill me: I
have deceived even your very eyes: what your wisdoms could not discover, these shallow fools have
brought to light, who in the night overheard me confessing to this man, how Don Iohn your brother incensed
me to slander the Lady Hero, how you were brought
into the Orchard, and saw me court Margaret in Heroes
garments, how you disgraced her when you should
marry her: my villainy they have upon record, which
I had rather seal with my death, than repeat over to
my shame: the Lady is dead upon mine and my masters
false accusation: and briefly, I desire nothing but the
reward of a villain.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Runs not this speech like iron through your
blood?

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.l: I have drunk poison whiles he uttered it.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: But did my Brother set thee on to this?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Yea, and paid me richly for the practise of it.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: He is composed and framed of treachery,
And fled he is upon this villainy.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.l: Sweet Hero, now thy image doth appear
In the rare semblance that I loved it first.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p:
Come, bring away the plaintiffs, by this time
our Sexton hath reformed Seignior Leonato of the matter:
and masters, do not forget to specify when time & place
shall serve, that I am an Ass.

sp.speaker: Con. 2.
sp.p:
Here, here comes master Seignior Leonato, and
the Sexton too.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Which is the villain? let me see his eyes,
That when I note another man like him,
I may avoid him: which of these is he?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: If you would know your wronger, look on me.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Art thou thou the slave that with thy breath
hast killed mine innocent child?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Yea, even I alone.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: No, not so villain, thou beliest thyself,
Here stand a pair of honourable men,
A third is fled that had a hand in it:
I thank you Princes for my daughters death,
Record it with your high and worthy deeds,
It was bravely done, if you bethink you of it.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.l: I know not how to pray your patience,
Yet I must speak, choose your revenge yourself,
Impose me to what penance your invention
Can lay upon my sin, yet sinned I not,
But in mistaking.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: By my soul nor I,
And yet to satisfy this good old man,
I would bend under any heavy weight,
That he will enjoin me to.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I cannot bid you bid my daughter live,
That were impossible, but I pray you both,
Possess the people in Messina here,
How innocent she died, and if your love
Can labour aught in sad invention,
Hang her an epitaph upon her tomb,
And sing it to her bones, sing it tonight:
Tomorrow morning come you to my house,
And since you could not be my son-in-law,
Be yet my Nephew: my brother hath a daughter,
Almost the copy of my child that is dead,
And she alone is heir to both of us,
Give her the right you should have given her cousin,
And so dies my revenge.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.l: O noble sir!
Your overkindness doth wring tears from me,
I do embrace your offer, and dispose
For henceforth of poor Claudio.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Tomorrow then I will expect your coming,
Tonight I take my leave, this naughty man
Shall face to face be brought to Margaret,
Who I believe was packed in all this wrong,
Hired to it by your brother.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: No by my soul she was not,
Nor knew not what she did when she spoke to me,
But always hath been just and virtuous,
In anything that I do know by her.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p:
Moreover sir, which indeed is not under white
and black, this plaintiff here, the offender did call me
ass, I beseech you let it be remembered in his punishment, and also the watch heard them talk of one Deformed, they say he wears a key in his ear and a lock hanging by it, and borrows money in Gods name, the which
he hath used so long, and never paid, that now men grow
hardhearted and will lend nothing for Gods sake: pray
you examine him upon that point.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I thank thee for thy care and honest pains.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p:
Your worship speaks like a most thankful
and reverend youth, and I praise God for you.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: There is for thy pains.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: God save the foundation.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
Go, I discharge thee of thy prisoner, and I
thank thee.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p:
I leave an arrant knave with your worship,
which I beseech your worship to correct yourself, for
the example of others: God keep your worship, I
wish your worship well, God restore you to health,
I humbly give you leave to depart, and if a merry meeting may be wished, God prohibit it: come
neighbour.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Until tomorrow morning, Lords, farewell.

sp.speaker: Brot.
sp.l: Farewell my Lords, we look for you tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: We will not fail.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.l: Tonight I will mourn with Hero.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Bring you these fellows on, we will talk with
Margaret, how her acquaintance grew with this lewd
fellow.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p:
Pray thee sweet Mistress Margaret, deserve
well at my hands, by helping me to the speech of Beatrice.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Will you then write me a Sonnet in praise of
my beauty?

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
In so high a style Margaret, that no man living
shall come over it, for in most comely truth thou deservest it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: To have no man come over me, why, shall I always keep below stairs?

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
Thy wit is as quick as the grey-hounds mouth,
it catches.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
And yours, as blunt as the Fencers foils, which
hit, but hurt not.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
A most manly wit Margaret, it will not hurt a
woman: and so I pray thee call Beatrice, I give thee the
bucklers.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Give us the swords, we have bucklers of our
own.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
If you use them Margaret, you must put in the
pikes with a vice, and they are dangerous weapons for
Maids.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Well, I will call Beatrice to you, who I think
hath legs.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p:
And therefore will come. The God of love that
sits above, and knows me, and knows me, how pitiful I deserve. I mean in singing, but in loving, Leander the good swimmer, Troilous the first employer of
panders, and a whole book full of these quondam carpet-mongers, whose name yet run smoothly in the even rode of a blank verse, why they were never so truly turned over and over as my poor self in love: marry I cannot show it rime, I have tried, I can find out no
rime to Lady but baby, an innocent time: for scorn,
horn, a hard time: for school fool, a babbling time:
very ominous endings, no, I was not born under a riming Planet, for I cannot woo in festival terms:
Enter Beatrice. sweet Beatrice wouldst thou come when I called
thee?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Yea Seignior, and depart when you bid me.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: O stay but till then.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
Then, is spoken: fare you well now, and yet ere
I go, let me go with that I came, which is, with knowing what hath past between you and Claudio.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
Only foul words, and thereupon I will kiss
thee.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
Foul words is but foul wind, and foul wind
is but foul breath, and foul breath is noisome, therefore I will depart unkissed.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
Thou hast frighted the word out of his right
sense, so forcible is thy wit, but I must tell thee plainly,
Claudio undergoes my challenge, and either I must shortly hear from him, or I will subscribe him a coward, and
I pray thee now tell me, for which of my bad parts didst
thou first fall in love with me?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
For them all together, which maintained so
politic a state of evil, that they will not admit any
good part to intermingle with them: but for which of
my good parts did you first suffer love for me?

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: Suffer love! a good epithet, I do suffer love indeed, for I love thee against my will.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
In spite of your heart I think, alas poor heart,
if you spite it for my sake, I will spite it for yours, for
I will never love that which my friend hates.

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.p: Thou and I are too wise to woo peaceably.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p:
It appears not in this confession, there is not one
wise man among twenty that will praise himself.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
An old, an old instance Beatrice, that lived in
the time of good neighbours, if a man do not erect in
this age his own tomb ere he dies, he shall live no
longer in monuments, then the Bels ring, & the Widow
weeps.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: And how long is that think you?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p:
Question, why an hour in clamour and a quarter in rheum, therefore is it most expedient for the wise,
if Don worm (his conscience) find no impediment to
the contrary, to be the trumpet of his own vertues, as
I am to myself so much for praising myself, who I
myself will bear witness is praise worthy, and now tell
me, how doth your cousin?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Very ill.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p: And how do you?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Very ill too.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
Serve God, love me, and mend, there will I leave
you too, for here comes one in haste.

sp.speaker: Vrs.
sp.p:
Madam, you must come to your Uncle, yonder is old coil at home, it is proved my Lady Hero hath been falsely accused, the Prince and Claudio
mightily abused, and Don Iohn is the author of all, who
is fled and gone: will you come presently?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Will you go hear this news Seignior?

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
I will live in thy heart, die in thy lap, and be buried in thy eyes: and moreover, I will go with thee to
thy Uncles.

div2.stage: Enter Claudio, Prince, and three or foure with Tapers.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.l: Is this the monument of Leonato?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: It is my Lord.
Done to death by slanderous tongues,
Was the Hero that here lies:
Death in guerdon of her wrongs,
Gives her fame which never dies:
So the life that died with shame,
Lives in death with glorious fame.
Hang thou there upon the tomb,
Praising her when I am dumb.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.l: Now music sound & sing your solemn hymn
Pardon goddess of the night,
Those that slew thy virgin knight,
For the which with songs of woe,
Round about her tomb they go:
Midnight assist our moan, help us to sigh and groan.
Heavily, heavily.
Graves yawn and yield your dead,
Till death be uttered,
Heavenly, heavenly.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.l: Now unto thy bones good night, yearly will I do this right.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Good morrow masters, put your Torches out,
The wolves have preyed, and look, the gentle day
Before the wheels of Phoebus, round about
Dapples the drowsy East with spots of grey:
Thanks to you all, and leave us, fare you well.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.l: Good morrow masters, each his several way.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Come let us hence, and put on other weeds,
And then to Leonatoes we will go.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.l: And Hymen now with luckier issue speeds,
Than this for whom we rendered up this woe.

div2.stage: Enter Leonato, Bene. Marg. Vrsula, old man, Frier, Hero.

sp.speaker: Frier.
sp.l: Did I not tell you she was innocent?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: So are the Prince and Claudio who accused her,
Upon the error that you heard debated:
But Margaret was in some fault for this,
Although against her will as it appears,
In the true course of all the question.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: Well, I am glad that all things sort so well.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.l: And so am I, being else by faith enforced
To call young Claudio to a reckoning for it.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Well daughter, and you gentlewomen all,
Withdraw into a chamber by yourselves,
And when I send for you, come hither masked:
The Prince and Claudio promised by this hour
To visit me, you know your office Brother,
You must be father to your brothers daughter,
And give her to young Claudio.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: Which I will do with confirmed countenance.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.l: Friar, I must entreat your pains, I think.

sp.speaker: Frier.
sp.l: To do what Seignior?

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.l: To bind me, or undo me, one of them:
Seignior Leonato, truth it is good Seignior,
Your niece regards me with an eye of favour.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: That eye my daughter lent her, it is most true.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.l: And I do with an eye of love requite her.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: The sight whereof I think you had from me,
From Claudio, and the Prince, but what is your will?

sp.speaker: Bened.
sp.l: Your answer sir is Enigmatical,
But for my will, my will is, your good will
May stand with ours, this day to be conjoined,
In the state of honourable marriage,
In which (good Friar) I shall desire your help.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: My heart is with your liking.

sp.speaker: Frier.
sp.l: And my help.

div2.stage: Enter Prince and Claudio, with attendants.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Good morrow to this fair assembly.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Good morrow Prince, good morrow Claudio:
We here attend you, are you yet determined,
Today to marry with my brothers daughter?

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: I will hold my mind were she an Ethiope.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Call her forth brother, here is the Friar ready.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Good morrow Benedicke, why what is the matter?
That you have such a February face,
So full of frost, of storm, and cloudiness.

sp.speaker: Claud.
sp.l: I think he thinks upon the savage bull:
Tush, fear not man, we will tip thy horns with gold,
And all Europa shall rejoice at thee,
As once Europa did at lusty Ioue,
When he would play the noble beast in love.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Bull Ioue sir, had an amiable low,
And some such strange bull leapt your fathers Cow,
A got a Calf in that same noble feat,
Much like to you, for you have just his bleat.

div2.stage: Enter brother, Hero, Beatrice, Margaret, Vrsula.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: For this I owe you: here comes other reckonings.
Which is the Lady I must seize upon?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: This same is she, and I do give you her.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Why then she is mine, sweet let me see your face.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: No that you shall not, till you take her hand,
Before this Friar, and swear to marry her.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.l: Give me your hand before this holy Friar,
I am your husband if you like of me.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.l: And when I lived I was your other wife,
And when you loved, you were my other husband.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.l: Another Hero?

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.l: Nothing certainer.
One Hero died, but I do live,
And surely as I live, I am a maid.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: The former Hero, Hero that is dead.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: She died my Lord, but whiles her slander lived.

sp.speaker: Frier.
sp.l: All this amazement can I qualify,
When after that the holy rites are ended,
I will tell you largely of fair Heroes death:
Mean time let wonder seem familiar,
And to the chapel let us presently.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Soft and fair Friar, which is Beatrice?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: I answer to that name, what is your will?

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.l: Do not you love me?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Why no, no more than reason.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.l: Why then your Uncle, and the Prince, & Claudio, have been deceived, they swore you did.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Do not you love me?

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.l: Troth no, no more than reason.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Why then my Cousin Margaret and Vrsula
Are much deceived, for they did swear you did.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.l: They swore you were almost sick for me.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: They swore you were well-nigh dead for me.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.l: It is no matter, then you do not love me?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: No truly, but in friendly recompense.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Come Cousin, I am sure you love the gentleman.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.l: And I will be sworn upon it, that he loves her,
For here is a paper written in his hand,
A halting sonnet of his own pure brain,
Fashioned to Beatrice.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.l: And here is another,
Writ in my cousins hand, stolen from her pocket,
Containing her affection unto Benedicke.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
A miracle, here is our own hands against our
hearts: come I will have thee, but by this light I take
thee for pity.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
I would not deny you, but by this good day, I
yield upon great persuasion, & partly to save your life,
for I was told, you were in a consumption.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Peace I will stop your mouth.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: How dost thou Benedicke the married man?

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
I will tell thee what Prince: a College of wit-crackers
cannot flout me out of my humour, dost thou
think I care for a Satyr or an Epigram? no, if a man will
be beaten with brains, he shall wear nothing handsome
about him: in brief, since I do purpose to marry, I will
think nothing to any purpose that the world can say against it, and therefore never flout at me, for I have said
against it: for man is a giddy thing, and this is my conclusion: for thy part Claudio, I did think to have beaten
thee, but in that thou art like to be my kinsman, live unbruised, and love my cousin.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p:
I had well hoped you wouldst have denied Beatrice, that
I might have cudgeled thee out of thy single life, to make
thee a double dealer, which out of question thou wilt be,
if my Cousin do not look exceeding narrowly to thee.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
Come, come, we are friends, let us have a dance
ere we are married, that we may lighten our own hearts,
and our wives heels.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: We will have dancing afterward.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
First, of my word, therefore play music. Prince,
thou art sad, get thee a wife, get thee a wife, there is no
staff more reverend than one tipped with horn.

sp.speaker: Messen.
sp.l: My Lord, your brother Iohn is tane in flight,
And brought with armed men back to Messina.

sp.speaker: Bene.
sp.p:
Think not on him till tomorrow, I will devise
thee brave punishments for him: strike up Pipers.
